TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. If the document 'Strategic Basis of Australian Defence Policy' leaked to the National Times does not represent the policy of the Government, why did Cabinet neither alter nor reject it in Perth on 19 September last? Indeed, why did it endorse it? If Cabinet has changed its policy, will the Minister advise what portions of the document do not represent Government policy?

—The honourable gentleman does not have the date right, but I do not suppose that is terribly important. The strategic basis document has never been adopted by any Cabinet as policy. Policy statements are made by the Government and by Ministers and are publicly announced where it is appropriate to do so. The document, as has happened on each occasion when the document has gone before Cabinet in the past, is endorsed as guidance for the preparation of recommendations on defence policy.
—That actually is not correct. There have been occasions when it has been returned for further consideration.

—I am not aware of the practice of past governments. But I am aware that when strategic guidance papers have been presented to Cabinet-they are first presented to the Minister for Defence and then, I expect, are considered by other Ministers before they go to Cabinet-they have been ultimately endorsed as guidance for the development of policy.
—You rubber stamped it. That means you endorsed it without question.

—I do not know whether the honourable gentleman is just making cheap political capital. I make one other point on this. The honourable gentleman has assumed incorrectly that a document published in a newspaper represents the actual text of a document which is dealt with by Cabinet. That is an assumption he is entitled to make. If that is the manner in which he treats important matters such as this, that is his business. We have neither denied nor confirmed its accuracy.
—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Has the Government taken any decision to develop a nuclear capability as claimed in an article published in the National Times on 30 March 1984?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can state categorically that the Government has never made any decision to acquire or develop a nuclear capability and has no intention of doing so; nor has the Cabinet or any Cabinet committee discussed the possible development of a nuclear capability by Australia. On 22 November 1983, Cabinet made decisions on arms control and disarmament, which have been announced, and I remind the House of them:

ANSWER.PARA: (i) to promote measures to halt and reverse the nuclear arms race;
(ii) to uphold the international nuclear non-proliferation treaty;
(iii) to promote a comprehensive and verifiable ban on nuclear testing;
(iv) to develop the concept of a nuclear free zone in the South Pacific;
(v) to support the achievement of an agreement to ban chemical weapons;
(vi) to support the process of negotiation and the achievement of balanced and verifiable arms control agreements;
(vii) to take an active role in pursuing arms control and disarmament measures wherever possible . . .
(viii) to affirm Australia's readiness to join a consensus to hold an international conference on the Indian Ocean zone of peace question.

The Government will neither confirm nor deny the accuracy of the purported extracts from the document 'Strategic Basis of Australian Defence Policy 1983', published in the National Times on 30 March this year. I say this: To the extent that a document of that title was considered by Cabinet last year it was, as the Attorney-General stated in another place on Friday, simply endorsed by way of guidance for the purposes of review of defence planning and for the development of Australian defence policies. As is well known, it is not a policy document, but to the extent that any policy prescriptions are contained in it, these were not specifically endorsed by the Cabinet.
The strategic basis document from which the National Times claimed to be quoting contains the following key sentence on the nuclear question, and I ask the House to take notice of this sentence:

Australia's interests continue to be served by adherence to, and support for wider acceptance of, the Treaty on Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and for strengthening nuclear safeguards measures generally.

I note that that crucially important sentence does not appear in the extracts in the National Times. The fact that that highly relevant sentence was not quoted would come as no surprise to anyone who knows anything about the National Times.

I conclude by saying this: I repeat that the commitment of this Government to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, which has been made clear in this place and in this country by me, and internationally in many forums by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, is complete and unequivocal. Mr Speaker, you will understand that the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty creates a permanent and binding obligation on Australia not to acquire nuclear weapons. We will not only honour that obligation, but this Government, in this country and around the world in all relevant forums, will do all in its efforts not merely to support that but to widen its application.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence. I say by way of introduction that it is absolute nonsense to say that a document may or may not exist and then to quote from the document and allege that the quotation does not match what is published in a newspaper. Therefore, the document exists. On that basis that document did recommend-I ask the question of the Minister-that should our neighbours acquire nuclear weapons, the Government ought to be prepared to give consideration to the acquisition of same. You endorsed that document. Could the Minister explain how the document could be so endorsed, albeit that it is only a guide, and yet stick to the principles of the Non- Proliferation Treaty?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the honourable gentleman fails to understand that the existence of a document does not automatically mean that the report in the National Times, from which he quotes, is accurate.
—He has quoted from it. Didn't you hear the answer a minute ago?

—The Prime Minister has indicated to the House that the report in the National Times, which purports to contain a quote, is not in fact accurate. He has indicated quite clearly what the Government's policy on nuclear weapons is, and remains, and will remain. He has indicated quite clearly that the article in the National Times is mischievous in the extreme in that it seeks to present a situation relating to Australian Labor Party policy and Government policy which is neither valid nor accurate; nor can it be supported by any examination of the announcements of policy or decisions made by this Government.

ANSWER.PARA: I am now aware that in the past recommended strategic basis papers have been sent back by former governments. They were sent back because they did not meet the short term political requirements of the Prime Minister of the day. He happened to be the same Prime Minister who had a resolution passed in this House declaring that we would be at war within two years. This resolution was designed for domestic political consumption and no more and was accompanied in the next Budget by a massive reduction in the defence vote. That is how significant and serious the Opposition is about forward planning and the need for a realistic and accurate appraisal of our strategic situation at any given time. I reiterate : The strategic basis document was prepared and presented to Cabinet by the Defence Committee and Cabinet endorsed it for guidance in the development of future defence policy. The Government will announce its defence policy, as it has already done absolutely and categorically on nuclear weapons, at such times as it is required and when reviews of decisions are desirable.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Does the Government, in determining its policy on arms control and disarmament issues , take as a premise that the Soviet Union has achieved strategic nuclear superiority over the United States and that this superiority has led to, or could lead to, a dangerous lack of political will on the American side?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no lack of political will on the part of the United States of America. I believe that that has been amply demonstrated by the way in which the Reagan Administration has committed itself to increased defence spending-it has done so successfully in the years of its administration-and in particular has invested money in the development of improved nuclear weaponry capability. But neither is there any lack of political will on the side of the other super-power , the Soviet Union. So lack of will is not the matter which influences us; rather it is the nuclear arms race escalation which disturbs us. It is against that, and in respect of all nuclear powers, that this Government has been working attentively in the areas of arms control, with the ultimate objective of nuclear disarmament being achieved.

ANSWER.PARA: I must say, as a melancholy conclusion arrived at many years ago, as a consequence of nuclear arms being extensively evident in the world today and the nature of arms escalation, that it is most unlikely that we will achieve nuclear disarmament in our lifetime. That would require all nuclear powers, not just the two super-powers, to determine at a given point that they would disband all nuclear weapons. That, I repeat, is most unlikely. Accordingly, arms control and , in the meantime, effective deterrence doctrines are supported by this Government.

The other part of the question which the honourable member presented to me was one of measurement of the relative capabilities of the two super-powers in respect of nuclear armaments. One is then confronted by the problem of asymmetrical differences. For example, the Soviet Union has more vehicles to carry weapons. It has more warheads. It has more explosive power. On the other hand, the Americans have much greater accuracy. I think the confusion and the complexities in trying to count these respective areas have been summed up in a paper entitled 'Management of the Superpower Balance' by Desmond Ball, a respected international authority in this field. In that paper he points out that the Soviet Union has 40 per cent more destructive capability in respect of countervalue or soft targets but in respect of hard targets or counterforce targets the United States has twice the destructive capability of the Soviet Union.

Taking these considerations on board, the obvious conclusion is not to spend time trying to work out who is edging ahead, who is sliding behind, who on balance has the greater destructive power or who is lagging but to recognise that both super-powers have sufficient capability to destroy themselves and the world with them many times over. Nothing sums up that and the fruitlessness finally of the arms race more than the fact that the Americans are moving towards an advanced strategic weapon, the MX missile, and the Soviet Union is moving to the SS-X-24 and the SS-X-25. The Americans are moving to the Stealth 1B bomber and the Soviet Union to the Blackjack bomber. The Soviet Union already has anti-satellite destructive capabilities. The Americans are moving to that capability with technology in advance of that of the Soviet Union. In that last matter we have reason to be particularly concerned because it could introduce into the equation between the nuclear capabilities of the super-powers an anti- ballistic missile capability which would be extraordinarily destabilising.

I do not propose to go any further except to stress the point I made a few seconds ago. The issue for us is not so much a matter of trying to carry out the calculations of who is ahead and who is behind and who is moving up and who is lagging as it is a matter of trying to stop what is a terribly fearsome race between the super-powers which already have the nuclear destructive capability to destroy this globe.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Defence accept that Australia's defence responsibilities extend to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island? In light of his statement that Cabinet has endorsed for guidance on future development of policy a strategic basis paper, will he advise the House what guidance he would give the inhabitants of those two islands in the event of an invasion or threatened invasion by a hostile power?

—I direct a question to the Minister for Health. Despite the current industrial action by some medical specialists in Australia, does the Minister have any information to indicate the level of acceptance of Medicare by medical practitioners generally?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Lilley for this particularly timely question. Yes, we have certain figures which indicate the response of the medical profession to the Medicare program. I think they suggest quite clearly a discrepancy between some of the militant noises made by the leadership of the profession and the actual actions of doctors on the ground.

ANSWER.PARA: We have, for the first seven weeks of Medicare, the bulk billing/direct billing program; that is, the number of services which have been bulk billed and/or direct billed. In New South Wales 5l.8 per cent of all services were bulk billed . In the Australian Capital Territory, unfortunately, only 18.8 per cent were bulk billed. That says something, I think, about the medical profession in this Territory. In Victoria 44.8 per cent of all services were bulk billed. In Queensland 49 per cent of all services were bulk billed. In South Australia the figure was 48.5 per cent, and in Western Australia it was 49.4 per cent. Therefore, across the country as a whole, in the first seven weeks of Medicare, out of 9.l million services, 4.4 million, or 48.5 per cent, were direct or bulk billed by doctors. I think that that gives a very clear indication indeed that many ordinary doctors throughout this country have accepted the basic principles inherent in Medicare. I believe that, if this threatened and quite unnecessary strike goes ahead, many of the medical profession in Australia will not accept the militant dictates of their leaders.

In the light of his response that because there is no threat of invasion to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands or Christmas Island there is no need to worry about defending them, I ask whether it is on that basis that the Minister is persisting in his attempts to run down the Australian Defence Force.

—We have come to expect the right honourable gentleman to misrepresent facts rather badly. The right honourable gentleman has misrepresented that proposition, as he misrepresents propositions on most occasions.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy. Is the Minister aware of the allegations in last weekend's Four Corners program about a laxity in Australia's nuclear safeguards system? Was Australia's current nuclear safeguards system put in place by the former Liberal-National Party Government? Is the question of this Labor Government tightening Australia's nuclear safeguards system being considered by the Australian Science and Technology Council, which is due to deliver its report by the middle of next month?

—I did not see the actual program referred to, but my colleague the Minister for Resources and Energy did. Of course, he has noted the response to the point of view put forward in that program. The Government wants to restate that it places the utmost importance on effective nuclear safeguards. On 10 November 1983 the Prime Minister announced the inquiry by the Australian Science and Technology Council to which the honourable member referred in his question. That ASTEC inquiry will be looking into this and other aspects of Australia's involvement in the nuclear fuel cycle. The inquiry is examining these things in particular: Australia's nuclear safeguards arrangements, giving particular attention to the effectiveness of the bilateral and multilateral agreements, and to the scope for strengthening these agreements; secondly, the opportunities for Australia through the conditions of its involvement in the nuclear fuel cycle to advance further the cause of nuclear non-proliferation, having regard to the policies and practices of recipient countries; and, thirdly , the adequacy of existing technology for handling and disposing of waste products by consumer countries, and the ways in which Australia can further contribute to the development of safe disposal methods. The inquiry is due to report in May. The Government will consider what specific action it needs to take in the light of the inquiry's findings.

Is it a fact that he failed to meet the provisions of his own Medicare legislation for the categorisation of private hospitals for the purposes of government subsidy and private insurance rebate? —Is the Minister for Science and Technology aware of the tremendous work being done by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in respect of the plant leucaena leucocephela? Does he believe that this plant will have a tremendous impact on agricultural production in Australia ? Is it evidence that technological advancement in Australia is not confined merely to plastic 'fish' and silicon 'chips'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Kalgoorlie for his question about leucaena leucocephela. In our part of the country people talk of little else. It is an important breakthrough. It is a leguminous plant, a native of Hawaii and some countries of South America. It will grow to somewhere between seven and 10 metres. It has a very high protein content-about 27 per cent. As a result, it has enormous potential as a food for ruminants. That is the good news . The bad news is that unfortunately it produces an amino acid called mimosine which has the effect of causing loss of hair and interferes with the action of the thyroid. I would not recommend it to some honourable members. For this reason in Australia it causes debilitating effects in areas where it constitutes 40 per cent or so of the diet. This has proved very difficult because it is a preferred food. The animals like it. If they like it, of course, they suffer the consequences. The interesting thing is that the disease has had these ill effects in Australia but it does not have the ill effects in Hawaii and in South America. So it has been a matter of identifying why it is different in Hawaii and South America and finding whether we can make sure that the plant would have purely beneficial effects here.

ANSWER.PARA: The CSIRO's technological breakthrough has been to discover that ruminants or cattle in other countries contain an anaerobic bacteria that destroys the mimosene. This is another achievement of the Hawke Government. This breakthrough has meant that cattle can now thrive on a diet of leucaena. In the Ord River valley it grows so well that carrying rates of nine beasts to the hectare are predicted for the summer maximum growth period and six beasts to the hectare during the winter. This technological breakthrough by the CSIRO means that the Ord River valley has the potential to produce more fat cattle than are currently produced by the whole of the Kimberleys or the Northern Territory. The bacteria, once introduced into ruminant cattle, is passed on by contact. It is a very great breakthrough and it may have the effect in the honourable member's electorate and in other areas in the north of Australia of turning unproductive areas into extremely productive ones. We ought to congratulate the CSIRO on another very important breakthrough.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Health not declared that his determination to retain Federal ministerial control over doctors' contracts with public hospitals , embodied in section 17 of the Health Insurance Amendment Act, stems from his objective of controlling Medicare costs? Is it true that contracts with diagnostic specialists in all States limit their charges to the schedule fee or less? Does this mean that cost savings will be achieved only by reducing schedule fees and extending the use of section 17 to other specialties? If not, why does the Minister insist on the all-embracing powers of section 17?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable member knows, the schedule fee guideline is the only requirement simply because the Government has already made major compromises and referred the other guidelines, which also relate to cost constraint in the field of diagnostic specialties, to the Penington Committee of Inquiry into Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals. The honourable member can make the point simply because the Government has already put aside other guidelines relating to cost constraint in the diagnostic specialist area to the consideration of the Penington inquiry.

ANSWER.PARA: I reiterate now for all honourable members the actions the Government has taken in this matter to meet the objections of the medical profession over this question. First of all, we have put aside all the controversial guidelines except the very straightforward one about the requirement that diagnostic specialists should charge no more than the schedule fee in public hospitals. Secondly, we have accepted the suggestion of the Australian Democrats that there should be parliamentary scrutiny over the Minister's powers in relation to these guidelines. Hopefully, that will pass through the Parliament on this occasion. Thirdly, I and the Prime Minister have promised the Australian Medical Association that we will accept any recommendation from Penington on the arbitration and consultative procedures in relation to section 17 which so concern the AMA. If any objective person examines the responses we have made it will be seen that the strike that is now threatened is perhaps the most self- indulgent and the most unjustified strike in this country's history.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Housing and Construction. Have there been some recent reports suggesting that there is a decline in construction activity in Australia? Can the Minister inform the House of the facts concerning this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been some reports over the weeks to that effect. In fact, I was hoping to get a question of this nature some weeks ago. As the weeks have gone by, I have been really rather glad that I did not get it earlier because the picture has improved every week, rather like my golf, which is on the improve. With my golf there are the occasional hiccups, but not so with the construction industry, which is on the steady improve. To understand the construction industry one has to divide it into three sectors. First of all, there is the housing construction industry. The report from the Indicative Planning Council, issued on Sunday, shows that the number of houses being constructed in this country has increased from the miserably low 105,000 in the previous financial year to what is expected to be 135,000 this financial year. We are hoping for 145,000 in the next financial year, and all this without any resource constraints, without any overheating.

ANSWER.PARA: In the case of the second sector, the engineering construction sector, I have to admit that the picture is not quite so good. That sector depends enormously on demand for our coal and iron ore. To the extent that it is possible for government to underpin the engineering construction sector, this Government has so underpinned it in the civil works program, in what it has achieved in new defence construction, and so on. In the case of the third sector, the other non- dwelling construction sector, which covers offices, factories, shops and so on, there the picture is better than in the engineering construction sector. Once again, this is thanks not only to the civil works program of the Commonwealth Government but also to the money we have made available through the gentleman's agreement, the Loan Council and the Premiers Conference, to the States, who have responded well through their public works program.

All in all, the picture is an excellent one. I draw the attention of the House to the contrast that is to what it would have been under these discredited people opposite. They would have had a deficit of $2 billion to $3 billion less than we have been prepared to have. That $2 billion to $3 billion would, to an enormous extent, have come out of the construction program of this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very interesting admission.

—It would have. That is from where honourable members opposite would have taken a lot of it. There would have been a much lesser amount. There would have been so much less construction in this country. Honourable members opposite are embarrassed by that because they know what lesser construction there would have been in this country. Overall, thanks to what this Government has produced in its Budget, thanks to its civil works program and thanks to the public works programs of the States, which have been financed enormously from this Parliament , there is a 3 per cent to 4 per cent increase in construction in this country.
—I address a question to the Treasurer. I refer him to the decision of the Victorian State Australian Labor Party conference--

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not have thought that the former Treasurer would have been up suggesting that anybody is dragging his feet on the question of deregulation when in fact he was responsible for commissioning the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System and then, by and large , apart from one or two minor matters, leaving the report to lie on the shelf to collect dust because he could not get a piece of tissue paper through Cabinet, much less a Cabinet submission. The former Government and the economic geniuses of the National Party-particularly the former Prime Minister, who was, I suppose , probably one of the most chronic regulators the Commonwealth Parliament has ever had-always lined up together and defeated all proposals to free up the financial system in any way. This Government thought that it was important to maintain the momentum of discussion in this country about the state of the economic system, which had remained pretty much as it was in the late 1940s and early 1950s. Some of the impetus to the discussion which the Campbell report produced had fallen by the wayside because of the inactivity of the former government. —What did you say at the time, Paul? We were going to let 10 banks in.

—Just hang on a second, George. ANSWER.PARA: You may recall, Mr Speaker, that when I was asked a similar question about this matter some time ago I said there would be a long and coherent discussion within my Party. That debate is going on and it will continue to go on, and decisions will be made. Indeed, as has been reported, we have already had very long discussions with the Martin committee. They have been very fruitful discussions. As a result of those discussions I will be bringing submissions to Cabinet. It is simply a matter of wait and see. TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs: Are young Australians born here or naturalised at risk due to a possible national service obligation if they return to certain European and East European nations? Has any Australian citizen been called up for military service in another nation? If not, what advice on this question would the Minister give young Australians proposing to travel overseas?

—There have been problems in the past in respect of some countries which have refused to recognise the naturalisation processes which former citizens of their countries have undergone in a new host residential country such as Australia. That certainly was the experience in the case of Greece, but I believe that that has been rectified. It was the experience in the case of at least one Eastern bloc country-I will have to check to make sure I am right in the one I name-but that too has been checked. PETITION.TITLE: Chiropractic Services

That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice and does nothing to reduce the high cost of health care in Australia.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The deep policy differences between the Ministers and the Departments of Defence and Defence Support and the adverse consequences of these for Australia' s national security.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department of Defence Support was formed in May 1982 under the Fraser Government. The purpose of that Department is to provide optimum support in peace and war to the Australian armed forces. It is the organisational, industrial and technical arm of our armed forces. Its importance to our national security is so obvious that it requires nothing further to be said on it. One would think that the person who was chosen by the Hawke Government to head this Department would be someone whose background, attributes and interests made him a fit and vigorous person to be there.

SPEECH.PARA: It was, therefore, with some astonishment that we learnt of the appointment of the present Minister for Defence Support (Mr Howe) to that job. He is by background a pacifist and a member of a peace movement. He is a left winger; that may be neither here nor there, I suppose. He is on record as being contrary to any military ties with the Asian nations and he has, indeed, signed a petition to that effect. Putting him in that position, with the whole of his predilections opposed to the military and opposed to our involvement with Asian nations, is rather like putting a vegetarian in charge of an abattoir. It is as apt as that.

What has happened in the year that he has been there? He and the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes), that man who lurches around within the Department of Defence looking anywhere at all for a policy, have been in continual and deep conflict. The conflict differences between them and between their departments are such as to cause a real danger to the development of the technical and military resources of this nation. The conflict between the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Defence Support has been remarked on enough in the media. But if one goes to some of the documents produced by the departments from which that conflict emerges, it becomes apparent that it is a very serious problem not just to this Government, but to the national interest.

For the purpose of examining those policy differences-policy differences which I might add are compounded by the Minister's inability to control his Department , by the lack of guidelines for that Department, and by the guerrilla warfare carried on by the two bureaucracies-let me go first of all to the Department of Defence Support's Estimates of Expenditure and Receipts 1983-84. At page 5 we see the following statement:

A matter still to be resolved relates to the Department's responsibility for the administration and management of programs and activities to develop the Australian industry necessary to support the nation's defence capability.

This is not a trivial matter; this is a matter of great importance. Why has it not been resolved? Why was it that by August of last year it was not resolved, and why has it yet not been resolved? We know of no reasons for that, because one is talking about policy differences between Ministers of this Government which are resolvable by this Government.

Let us go next to the submissions which were presented to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, which was looking into Australia's defence co-operation with its neighbours in the Asian region. Two sets of submissions were put in, one by the Department of Defence and one by the Department of Defence Support. Those submissions are irreconcilable. Not only do they come from different departments, but they also express quite different viewpoints. The Department of Defence had this to say in its original submission of August 1983:
The broad objective of our participation in Defence Cooperation Programs . . . is to promote the national independence of participating countries.

To promote national independence, the Department said, was the broad objective. To make this absolutely clear, it came back to this theme in a later paper, which went to the Senate Standing Committee in February of this year. The Department said:

The overall DCP is conducted for mutual benefit and while it assists in introducing Australian defence industry to the region it is not, and has not been encouraged to become, an arrangement for promoting the sale and export of Australian-produced defence equipment.

I raised this matter with the Minister in the adjournment debate some few days ago, and I will come to his answer in a few minutes. What did his Department have to say? The Department put in a submission in August 1983, a submission which remained as it stood and was circulated to members of the Senate Committee until some last-minute alterations were made by the Minister. These alterations were so last minute that his Department did not even have the courtesy to retype the document. The Minister's last minute notice of what his Department was saying was exposed in all its nakedness. What did it say? In one part which remains on record as part of the submission which went officially to the Senate Committee and was not excised, it said this:

A significant advantage to Australia's defence-related industries of encouraging Australian made military products to be provided, is that the recipient countries tend to ''lock-in'' to our goods and services when they are eventually in a position to buy these.

If one reads that statement and if one reads what else was said, it is perfectly plain that this submission was quite inconsistent with the Defence Department's view that the Department and the policy it was dealing with were there to promote national independence of neighbouring countries. It is a question, no doubt, of which is the best policy, but why is it impossible for this Government to have one policy on one question, which quite obviously it is?

This throws into relief the lack of direction in defence planning in this Government. For those who hastily excuse this Government on the basis that it has been in power for only one year, let me remind honourable members that the Government, when it comes to planning defence policy, is doing just that. It is not spending money; it is planning policy. One would think that it is quite capable of coming to some kind of conclusion about its defence policies within a year or so; but that has not been the case, as we all know. At page 57 the Auditor-General says:

The inability of Defence to define the strategic capabilities it required for munitions creates fundamental problems for Defence Support and its factories in planning, factory plant capability and rationalisation programs. It is not without significant cost implications and does not encourage local production.

So there we have it. We have clashes between the Ministers, which are well known , we have clashes between the departments, and we have a complete lack of policy planning and direction so that the Department of Defence Support does not know what it should do or when it should do anything at all.

Let us look at some of the differences between the Minister and his own Department. That, one might think, makes far worse the kinds of problems that the Government and the Australian people are experiencing because it is their security which is dependent on the decisions made by this Government. We know that the Minister put the submission in or, to be more accurate, the Department did. We know that the Minister could not have seen it when it went in even though it must have had his imprimatur because he made last minute changes. One might think that the changes were made or were allowed to go by the Department in the form in which they did with malice aforethought for the purpose of exposing the differences between the Minister and his Department because it would have taken a matter of a few minutes to have the document re-set. Be that as it may, we see that the Minister makes these last minute changes. It is finally drawn to his attention that his officers are going to give evidence the following day or so before a Senate committee and he explains these changes. He explained them to me when I raised them with him. Amongst other things, he said:

I removed what I thought were in many respects some misleading statements. I refer particularly to the reference to the creation of the situation of technological dependence within the Asian region. I think that that statement could be interpreted as reflecting an insensitivity which could be certainly misunderstood within the region. I wanted to ensure that that misinterpretation was not possible.

So he makes his position quite clear, one might think. He says that he does not want us to be talking about dependence on Australia by other countries within the Asian region. Whilst when he hurriedly went through the submission he excised certain parts of it, he left in parts of it. One of the parts he left in is irreconcilably in conflict with his own statement in this House because, I remind the House again, he left in part of the submission that related to locking in, as it was said, other countries to our technologies. One can say only two things of him. If he meant what he said in the adjournment debate in the Parliament, he had not understood his own Department's submission when it was at last put in and he had not understood what he was doing when he made those corrections to that submission. That illustrates clearly enough not only a fundamental lack of interest in his job, which is understandable enough given his background, but as well the deep differences between the Minister and his Department and the lack of control by the Minister over his Department, which apparently did not know for eight months what his views were on the subject on which it was putting in a submission to the Senate Committee. On top of that we have endemic guerrilla warfare between the two departments which is too well known to need to spend time on. It is critical that those departments should work together.

The submissions to which I have referred make that plain, as, indeed, does the recent example of the Minister putting up a proposal for 40 per cent offsets and a refusal to deal with those companies which were not up to date with their offset commitments. How could the Minister be putting up a submission quite contrary to the view of the Minister for Defence? It defies logic, and it defies any sort of order within this Government.

As I have said, it is not this time open to the Minister to excuse himself on the basis of time. A year is enough to work out one's problems. A year is more than enough to understand what the job is that one has to do. Here we have these two Ministers and these two departments in direct and continual conflict on matters of great national interest. It would be really hard to find a more important subject. How, for example, is Defence Support to plan if no plan is given to it? One might say, in passing, that the absence of policy guidelines is illustrated by that superb document, the strategic basis paper, which the Minister for Defence, in his usual acute manner, said was endorsed for guidance for future defence policy. What can one extract from that paper? It could have been written by an intelligent 14-year-old with an interest in Australia's military interests and military problems and future military problems.

Therefore, let us come in total to the problems that the Minister presents and the problems that the two Ministers present to the people of this country. First , there is no agreement on policy between the two Ministers; there is fundamental disagreement. Secondly, there is no agreement on policy between the two departments; there is fundamental disagreement and continuing guerrilla warfare between those departments. Thirdly, there has been no attempt to lay down any basis on which this country should be planning its future defence needs and on which the Department of Defence Support should be planning its industry and technical needs into the year 2000. Plans of that kind are not just necessary; they are essential if we are to guarantee to the people of this country not that they may be secure if they are lucky, but that they will be secure because we, the legislators of this country, will make sure, by planning, by thinking through to the future and by making the hard decisions, that they will be secure. As it is, it is only by guess and by God that we shall get through. This Government now needs to get hold of the Ministers and the bureaucrats and to put them into line.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I heard last week the speech of the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) I did not think that we would get a worse speech on the matter of defence, but I think that the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) has produced just that. What an extraordinary lack of substance in a speech about defence. Let us just run through some of the principal points. The honourable member's speech began with a bit of personality analysis by suggesting that I was somehow a pacifist. That has been suggested from time to time, but never by me. In terms of whatever my particular beliefs may be, the Government is made up of Ministers whose fundamental commitment is to Government policy. Whilst the matter of public importance centred on differences over policy, I thought that the honourable member for North Sydney was singularly unable to find one case in which there was a substantial difference. In the first place, it also showed a misunderstanding of arrangements set in place primarily by the previous Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me recall the circumstances in which the Department of Defence Support was created. It was created in May 1982 following a Defence Review Committee report in which John Utz played a leading role. The purpose of the Department was to gather together certain functions in support of the Defence Force and within the context of defence policy. I have never suggested, nor has anyone in my Department, that the Department of Defence Support, particularly with respect to all of those defence industry matters under our purview, operates in any way other than under the overall policies of the Department of Defence within the context of government policy. The Department of Defence Support is not a policy department.

The second issue that was raised is the matter of conflict over budget. Again, the Department of Defence Support has not, either under the previous Government or under this Government, had a budget which is distinguishable from the defence budget. Indeed, in our approach to the budgetary process we have to operate very much within the context of the overall defence budget. So, of course, there is a great deal of discussion with Defence over the level of funding that is available for the Department of Defence Support. (Quorum formed). Our budget is worked out very much within the context of the overall defence vote. So, insofar as there is discussion and debate, that debate occurs primarily within the Defence portfolio. To suggest that there would be no conflict of interest would be quite wrong, but that conflict was resolved, necessarily, within the time period for last year's Budget and it will happen quite successfully this year.

Other references have been made to policy differences. As to the reference to the departmental submission, I think I have made it very clear that it was not for departmental people to discuss with a committee matters of policy. Certainly , in terms of the thrust of what I saw in what was being proposed, there was an emphasis that seemed to me to be inconsistent with defence policy, an emphasis that I would reject as being part of the Government's policy. We are not on about creating technological dependence within the region and we are not on about locking people in, so I suggested that the most offending clauses be removed. There may be some problems surrounding the way in which that was done; but, if we are to discuss a matter of public importance about policy, let us talk about policy differences and not about trivia. Again, there is not a jot of policy within the report of the Auditor-General to which the honourable member for North Sydney referred. The report essentially comments on administrative problems, not matters of policy.

In summing it all up, no suggestion of any substance has been made of a difference in policy matters between the Minister and me, between my Department and the Department of Defence, or between me and the Government. Indeed, in broad policy terms, the shadow Minister, the honourable member for North Sydney, has not been able to put his finger on any problems.

If we are going to talk about problems within the area of the defence industry, we have to go back beyond the past 12 months. We have, in the area of the defence industry-an industrial capability in this country-a legacy of neglect. One does not need to go very far to find the evidence of that neglect. One can go to one or any of the establishments within my portfolio and one will find that, in the post-war period, very often the buildings, the plant and the machinery and the capability that has been retained is not the capability of the 1960s, the 1970s or the 1980s but a capability of the 1940s. I refer to the most recent report of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works brought down last week-I noticed that the shadow Minister did not refer to it-entitled ' Reconstruction of Pyrotechnic Section at the Munitions Filling Factory', at St Marys. In talking about the necessity for that facility the Committee said:

Little change has occurred since the 1950s, and today many buildings are in poor condition. Building deterioration has been accentuated . . . by inadequate funding for programmed maintenance, and a number of buildings have developed structural defects such as cracked walls and subsided floors.

The report goes on to describe the safety problems associated with that factory, safety problems so serious that it led to a Committee of Inquiry into Occupational Safety and Health at Munitions Filling Factory in August 1980. The workers in one of the most dangerous facilities that we have in the government factories in this country were not being protected in the 30 years or 40 years of conservative rule. Those workers were being exposed to terrible dangers that ought to have been engineered out of existence. This Government will have to allocate the $17m necessary to provide the proper facility. One does not have to go simply to St Marys.

One can go to Albion explosives factory in the outer western suburbs of Melbourne-the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) should go there-to look at the conditions under which people are working in that factory. The honourable member should have a look at the capital neglect there. Or he could go to the dockyards. I do not think anyone would suggest that the dockyards, despite the money that has been spent on modernisation, represent a safe working environment for people within the modern context. The honourable member could go to the Government Aircraft Factories. In many of its sections it reflects a very good historical picture of what an aircraft factory was like in the 1940s. One could go also to the Government Ordnance Factories and find obsolete equipment and machinery, lack of changerooms and proper facilities and a lack of emphasis on maintaining the capabilities and the skills of what is often a very special and particular work force with a very important contribution to make to the defence industry.

There is a massive problem in this country in terms of the defence industry which is not the product of a government that has been in office for 12 months. Anyone who thought that would be totally misguided. It is a product of a lack of a commitment to maintaining industrial capability in this country as it is relevant for defence over very many years.

To suggest that we have not been tackling these problems with a great deal of expedition and, indeed, with the very strong support of the Department of Defence, demonstrates that the honourable member has not moved around and looked to see what is happening. For the first time we are developing a corporate planning process in government factories. We are setting some objectives and we are aiming to measure the performance of those factories against defined corporate objectives. For the first time we are installing commercial accounting systems so that it is possible, at the Government Aircraft Factories, Williamstown Naval Dockyard and many other establishments to measure the performance in commercial terms. For the first time we are developing standards in occupational health and safety. The agreement at Williamstown Naval Dockyard was the first agreement of its type signed in a major plant anywhere in Australia.

We are making an agreement with the trade union movement with respect to occupational health and safety that will cover every establishment within the Department. This is an important by-product of the prices and incomes accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. We are making a commitment within the Department to improve management practice, and I think we will see massive management reform not only at Williamstown but also at the Government Aircraft Factories and many of our other establishments. We are introducing a consultative arrangement in which major decisions in the factory, or in any of our factories and establishments, will follow consultation with the work force. We are upgrading training standards. As with so much of Australian manufacturing industry, our work force, skilled as they may be and internationally highly efficient, have never been retrained. I was in Sweden last year where 5 per cent of the work force were in retraining. In one defence factory I visited, the whole of the work force had been retrained over a specified period. These changes that are occurring, the new capital investment, the attempt to build up our plant and machinery and to restore buildings, cannot be made overnight, but I believe that in the past 12 months this Government has made an important start . None of what I have suggested is controversial in policy terms. I think the Department of Defence and the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) fully support all we are attempting to achieve in those areas.

It ill becomes the honourable member for North Sydney to come into this House and talk about policy differences as if there is something of substance there; yet when he gets down to it he is not able to point to a single issue of any substance. Indeed, that is what has been wrong with the Liberal Party of Australia and with the conservative parties in the post-war period in Australia. They have never been concerned about the development of policy. They have never thought in the long term. Is the honourable member for North Sydney suggesting to me that in the 1950s there was long term planning for defence industry in this country, or indeed long term planning for defence? Successive conservative governments have lived by the seat of their pants on defence matters. We know why the build-up occurred after 1980. Was it a result of some planning process? No, it was all to do with something that happened in Afghanistan and a change in the situation that was not thought through and not developed in terms of Australia's defence policy. So we were going to have defence spending increasing in real terms by 6 per cent, 7 per cent and sometimes 10 per cent a year. No doubt the right honourable member for New England would have it at 15 per cent or 20 per cent a year. That was not on, it was never on, and our problems flow from that.

Defence policy has to be rethought. We have to consider the options. This Government in the past 12 months has made some tough decisions on both sides of the ledger. We have said there is no room for aircraft carriers in the Fleet Air Arm, but on the other hand we have said we will spend $800m building the FFGs in Australia because that will install a capability within the country in terms of shipbuilding and ship repair and being able to build a navy around Australian capacity and Australian interests. The talk of differences between the Minister for Defence and me and of differences in the Government in the area of defence, is just so much humbug and reflects a superficiality which, in turn, is based on a lack of concern. The honourable member for North Sydney has some policy ideas. Let us hear those policy ideas and not humbug.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate on this Bill is resumed, I remind the House that it has been agreed to have a general debate covering this Bill, the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Bill 1984 and the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Bill 1984.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not propose to canvass some of the wider issues raised in this debate last week, such as the resource rent tax advocated by the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) and the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous), except to say that one would not have a bar of the Government's typically socialist proposals in that area, which would be bound to distort exploration and investment decisions and inhibit the maintenance of a high level of oil self-sufficiency in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to speak specifically on the subject matter of this legislation. As I said at the beginning of my remarks the other day, the House will have noted that the Opposition's spokesman has entered some important reservations about this legislation. However, there should be no doubt that the Opposition does not oppose this legislation, which proposes a compromise solution to a near intractable situation. It is perhaps unnecessary to traverse all of the ground, but these Bills are the culmination of representations by the so-called northern refiners-the Amoco and Ampol companies in Brisbane and the Caltex company in Sydney-to governments, representations which date back to the time of the introduction of the crude oil absorption scheme in September 1970, when it was deemed obligatory that each refiner/ marketer should take a share of the indigenous Bass Strait crude production. That was, of course, before the quadrupling of the world oil price which followed the Middle East war of 1973.

An integral part of the crude oil absorption scheme was a freight allowance, then 9c a barrel, which was deducted from the f.o.b. price paid to the crude oil producer regardless of the cost of getting that oil to the respective refineries . This allowance was increased in recent times to 36c a barrel. However, that created a considerable competitive imbalance in the crude absorption system, as it favoured the low transportation costs of the so-called southern refiners-that is, the Shell, BP, Esso and Mobil companies-at the expense of the northern refiners, Amoco, Ampol, Caltex and, to a lesser extent, Shell at Clyde in Sydney . In fact, an over-recovery of costs is enjoyed by the southern refiners, as the southern refiners receive the 36c, transport the crude primarily by pipeline and incur costs of up to 14c a barrel with the average much less than that, whereas the northern refiners also receive the 36c but incur costs of upwards of $1 a barrel.

The nub of this issue, then, is that for years-though in its early stages with less severity-Ampol and Amoco in Brisbane and Caltex and the small Shell refinery in Sydney have been at an acute competitive disadvantage as the cost of getting their crude oil to their refineries has been higher than other refiners. This additional cost cannot be recovered under the refinery exchange arrangements that prevail in the industry and the government policy of a common capital city price for petroleum products.

These Bills, which provide that 20c of the 36c will go to a fund to be redistributed more in line with the higher transportation costs of the northern refiners, go a long way towards correcting an anomalous situation which has cost those companies, or rather their shareholders, a very considerable sum of money. Of course, on the other side, the southern refiners argue that they are entitled to the advantage of their superior locations. That is what makes the issue, as I said, such an intractable one.

However, even with the proposed arrangements, there are still difficulties. For example, there can be reasonable concern among the northern refiners that as freight costs rise, both pipeline and shipping, thus increasing the total transportation allowance under the crude absorption system, the proportion of the fixed 20c a barrel reallocation money to the total allowance, will again become adverse for the northern refiners. I say in that respect that it is hoped that after a trial period and a study of whether the competitive imbalance has been significantly adjusted and, indeed, in the light of the future of the crude absorption scheme itself, the Government will further review the arrangements.

However, notwithstanding this and other aspects raised by the Opposition's spokesman, as I said at the outset of my remarks for my part I commend the Bills as significantly correcting this inequitable and difficult situation which has been institutionalised through past government regulation. In particular, it will enable the Caltex operation in my State to be more cost efficient and competitive in the market place, and thus sustain its employment and investment position in New South Wales.

Representations from refiners to the Minister for Resources and Energy in the middle of last year were such that it was clear that the industry, following its inability to resolve the matter itself, expected some government action. The honourable member for Franklin also referred to the price of liquefied petroleum gas. I should remind honourable members that as recently as 28 March 1984 the wholesale price of automotive LPG was reduced by 3c a litre. LPG is not cheaper in Japan than in Australia. The honourable member for Flinders raised issues and a number of questions relating to the closure of the British Petroleum company's Westernport refinery. Most of those questions should actually be directed to BP. They are not, in the first instance, matters for government to determine. But it is relevant to note that the present refining capacity in Australia is between 820,000 and 850,000 barrels a day. The forecast product demand in 1984-85 is 590,000 barrels a day. The closure of the Crib Point refinery will remove 60,000 barrels a day from Australia's refining capacity. The closure will lead to increased utilisation in the remaining refineries and, because of its hardware, Crib Point is probably the least efficient of Australia's refineries. I again thank honourable members for their contributions to the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I, . . . renouncing all other allegiance, swear by Almighty God that I will be faithful and bear true allegiance to Her Majesty Elizabeth the Second, Queen of Australia, Her heirs and successors according to law, and that I will faithfully observe the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.
That is contained in Schedule 2 of the Australian Citizenship Act 1973. The affirmation of allegiance is in the following terms:

I, . . . renouncing all other allegiance, solemnly and sincerely promise and declare that I will be faithful, and bear true allegiance to Her Majesty Elizabeth the Second, Queen of Australia, Her heirs and successors according to law, and that I will faithfully observe the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.

Those amendments were brought in by the Hon. E. G. Whitlam, Labor Prime Minister of Australia. They were accepted by the overwhelming majority of Australians at that time, and from 1973 Her Majesty has been designated Queen of Australia. I see that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) is at the table. Let me say to the Minister that the other day I and many others were appalled to hear the Minister say in front of 25,000 people that he would amend the oath of allegiance so that to become an Australian citizen, to quote his words: 'You will not have to swear allegiance to a monarch living in a foreign country'. Let me say that both in law and in fact the Minister was wrong, and badly wrong, because the law is that one must swear an oath of allegiance to Her Majesty, Elizabeth the Second, Queen of Australia. One does not swear an oath of allegiance to the British Crown. One does not swear an oath of allegiance to a foreign monarch; one swears an oath of allegiance to the Queen of Australia. That is logical because our Constitution guarantees a parliamentary democracy under a constitutional monarchy.

Let there be no doubt about that, because if one looks at the preamble to the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia, the most important legal document in this nation, one will see in the recitation that the various States have ' agreed to unite in one indissoluble Federal Commonwealth under the Crown'. That is what the Constitution says. That is the constitutional birthright of every Australian whether he or she was born in this country or has adopted this country. Migrants know that under our Constitution they are coming to a country in which the Constitution guarantees three things: A parliamentary democracy, and an indissoluble Federal system, under the Crown. Nobody, not the Prime Minister, not the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, not the Australian Labor Party, has the right to take away unilaterally that which is the constitutional birthright of every Australian. But oh, how honourable members opposite hate the monarchy-except when the monarchy is in Australia! Then good Liberal Party and National Party members, the loyal members, cannot get within cooee of the Queen and the royal family because of Labor politicians falling all over themselves to be near her.

I ask honourable members to cast their minds back to last year. Who, when in England, put his arm around the Queen Mother? It was the same Prime Minister who today laughed and sneered when I introduced into this Parliament a notice of motion pointing out his double standards. That is the same Prime Minister who last year swore-I repeat 'swore'-an oath of allegiance when he became Prime Minister of this country. He did not do it privately; he did it at Yarralumla in the presence of the Governor-General and about 20 television cameras. The whole thing was televised nationally. The Prime Minister of Australia swore an oath of allegiance to Her Majesty the Queen of Australia, and today his Government, without any mandate whatsoever, is legislating to take out of the oath of allegiance and the affirmation of allegiance, which believe it or not will become a pledge-I will talk about that later-all reference to the Queen of Australia.

Make no mistake, Madam Deputy Speaker, honourable members and my fellow Australians, this Bill is the first step of the Hawke socialist Government in its endeavours to turn Australia into a republic against the wishes of the overwhelming majority of Australians. The Prime Minister is not the President of Australia and he and his Government have no election mandate whatsoever to remove the name of the Queen of Australia from anything. Who does the Prime Minister think he is? Power, I suggest, has obviously gone to his head. Did he stand in the Sydney Opera House last year and say: 'If you elect me as Prime Minister of Australia my Government will destroy the oath of allegiance and the affirmation of allegiance by ripping out of them reference to the Queen of Australia'?

This legislation removing reference to the Queen from the oath of allegiance is blatantly pro-republican. It is against the wishes of the overwhelming majority of Australians. The latest public opinion polls show that two out of three Australians are dead against this country being turned into a republic; and we in Her Majesty's loyal Opposition agree with them. The fact is that this legislation is the most politically and emotionally divisive that has been brought in to date by the Hawke socialist Government. It will cause considerable conflict within the Australian community and, in the opinion of some, it constitutes quasi-treason. Her Majesty's loyal Opposition tells the Prime Minister that he is not above the Queen and never will be. I might say just in passing that it is only because the latest public opinion polls show that 81 per cent of Australians believe in God that the Prime Minister has backed off the original intention of the Government to take reference to God out of the oath as well. At one stage last year we were going to have an oath of allegiance that had no reference at all in it to the Queen, and the Prime Minister thought that he had really joined the big time and was going to take out reference to God as well. He has not gone on with that.

We remind the Prime Minister that when he publicly swore that oath of allegiance to the Queen when he took office as Prime Minister of Australia last year, in a ceremony which was nationally televised, he was pledging his allegiance as Prime Minister to the Queen of Australia. Yet today the Hawke socialist Government is legislating to remove all references to the Queen from the oath of allegiance. The Prime Minister of Australia is now saying that allegiance to the Queen is not necessary for somebody to obtain Australian citizenship. What double standards! What hypocrisy! The oath of allegiance is necessary for the Prime Minister of Australia. It is necessary before a single member or senator can take his or her seat in this Parliament or in any of the State parliaments. But the Prime Minister, this great man, this man whose power has gone to his head, says that one does not have to take the oath of allegiance to the Queen to become an Australian citizen.

By law all Australians born in this country owe allegiance to the Queen of Australia without having to take any oath of allegiance. The Hawke socialist Government now proposes to create two classes of Australians-those who owe allegiance to the Queen and those who do not. The Prime Minister, aided and abetted by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, urged on by the mad socialist Left, the republican rabble in the Australian Labor Party, has decided that his Government will use its numbers to force this radical, republican proposal through the House of Representatives. I hope, and Her Majesty's loyal Opposition hopes, that wiser counsel will prevail in the Senate and that this disgraceful amendment will be defeated.

Not only have the Prime Minister and his Government been quite hypocritical on this issue; they have also been quite cowardly. Why do I say that? I say that because the Constitution itself provides the form of the oath of allegiance and the affirmation of allegiance before anybody can take his or her seat in this Parliament. I will read to the people of Australia the oath of allegiance as set out under our Constitution:
I, A.B., do swear that I will be faithful and bear true allegiance to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth, Her heirs and successors according to law. So help me God.
The affirmation reads:
I, A.B., do solemnly and sincerely affirm and declare that I will be faithful and bear true allegiance to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth, Her heirs and successors according to law.

What are we going to have now? Under this incredibly crazy Hawke socialist Government and its socialist Left Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs we are going to have the situation that to become an Australian citizen one does not need to take the oath of allegiance to the Queen but that to become a member of Parliament, to join the armed forces or to join the diplomatic corps one does . Having attended citizenship ceremonies in my home State of Tasmania for over 16 years as both a member of the Tasmanian Parliament and a member of the Federal Parliament, I have had not one single complaint about the oath of allegiance or the affirmation of allegiance. The Minister, listening to the socialist Left, the republican rabble, has said: 'This is a bit rough, getting people to swear allegiance to the Queen'. He told 25,000 people--
