SPEECH.PARA: I support the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1983 in the knowledge that the rationale behind the proposed changes embodies the Australian Labor Party Government's acceptance of the fact that the majority of people living in Australia do so with a proud and genuine commitment to our country's national identity. It is with this sense of national identity in mind that the proposals for change have been considered and put forward. It is to this Government's credit that it is committed to ensuring that the Australian Citizenship Act reflects the national identity of all Australians; that it does not discriminate between persons on the basis of sex, marital status and present or previous nationality; and that provision is made for a review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal should decisions arise to deny or deprive persons of citizenship under the Act. The Government's aim is to embody a thoroughly Australian character in the Act. This Bill will put the commitments of this Government into effect.

The Bill, proposing extensive amendments to the Citizenship Act, was introduced in this Parliament on 7 December 1983 by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West)-a very fine Minister, as we all know. The Minister is to be commended for putting forward this legislation which, in the long term, will be of benefit to Australia's new residents. The Bill is the result of the most extensive review of the Citizenship Act since it was passed by the Chifley Labor Government in 1948. The fact that the Act has not been changed since 1948 is either a tribute to the fine work of that Government or an indication that subsequent governments have seen no reason to acknowledge the changing nature of migration patterns in this country.

Our country has come a long way since those post-war years, which heralded a very active and successful migration program, a program which was to intermingle our own unique Australian culture with those of European and Asian origin. Australia since has become a culturally diverse society, an enriching feature giving way to a term more commonly used today-that of multiculturalism. The relationship between multiculturalism and national identity is very important in the context of this legislation. Clearly, while giving full respect to ethnic background, the Government wants to encourage those people who are eligible to take out Australian citizenship to do so in order that they may assume the associated rights and responsibilities of citizens of Australia and participate fully within the framework of our national identity. This Government believes that the measures contained in this legislation will assist those who wish to become citizens while at the same time removing from the existing Act what some may see as disincentives to the acquisition of citizenship. In considering the proposed amendments it needs to be appreciated that Australian citizenship was not in existence before January 1949. Until that time all persons living in Australia were simply either British subjects or aliens. There are still many provisions in the current Act which reflect this historical fact.

The decision to migrate to another country is a very serious and important one to the people concerned. There are many factors to be weighed and assessed, not to mention the emotional effects of such considerations. But, our new residents having made the decision to migrate to Australia and having successfully completed the lengthy migrant application processes, it is the wish of this Government warmly to welcome them and give them every opportunity readily to take on a very meaningful and happy life in their new home. Many people genuinely wish to become Australian citizens, taking on the accompanying responsibilities and rights, as soon as possible after taking up residence. But an estimated 1.2 million residents remain non-citizens although they qualify for citizenship. The Government wishes to see those people in the residentially eligible category take out citizenship in the new homeland of their choice so that they can enjoy the benefits and assume to their full potential their rightful place in our national identity.

Let me emphasise here that although a large number of people have not taken out citizenship the number applying for citizenship status has increased quite rapidly in recent years-from 78,000 in 1981-82 to 101,000 in 1982-83. A similar increase rate is occurring this year and it is the Government's intention to give encouragement to this trend, as it undoubtedly stems from a real pride in Australia and the status of Australian citizenship. It is this conviction of the 'proud Australian' that marks this legislation with a genuine pattern of national pride and a wish to share this sentiment with those people who have chosen Australia as their new home.

Since taking office as the member for Chisholm I have attended many citizenship ceremonies in my electorate. I am proud to have been in a position to welcome new citizens from very diverse backgrounds and to see at first hand how important the citizenship ceremony is to each one of them. My electorate of Chisholm encompasses a large migrant population and hardly a day goes by without visits to my electorate office from people who have migrated to Australia in search of a more rewarding life. The reasons for their visits vary. What has been proved to me from my conversations with such visitors is that the migrant constituency within Chisholm is a very vibrant one. It is one which provides many examples of community and family support and activity by which we can all benefit.

What does this Citizenship Amendment Bill do? The Bill alleviates many existing problems and addresses itself to making the process of citizenship much easier and more agreeable to all concerned. Among other things, it reduces the qualifying period from three years residence in the previous eight years to two years residence in the previous five years. I believe that once a person has made the decision to migrate to Australia, once a person has gone through those endlessly long processes-security checks, health checks, sponsorship and all of the things associated with migration-and has still decided to come here and make this place his or her home, it is not up to this Government to make the process of obtaining citizenship lengthy and arduous. This Bill recognises the fact that the decision to try to obtain Australian citizenship is very often made in the new citizen's own country and that the applicant has already seen himself or herself as attached to Australia for some time before coming here.

The Bill allows for appeals on a number of grounds to be directed to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the Government, or the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs no longer has the final determining powers in these cases. A demonstration of an adequate knowledge of English is no longer to be a requirement. A basic knowledge of English is the new requirement under these amendments. Applicants over 50 years of age will be exempted from the basic English requirement. People can question the logic about the words 'adequate' and 'basic' if they like but the fact of the matter is-this Bill recognises this fact-that many people who apply for citizenship and gain citizenship by going through a citizenship ceremony have only a basic knowledge of English. But the fact that they are acquiring Australian citizenship by their own choice is evidence enough of their intention to acquire the language of this country. They will certainly operate better with a good knowledge of the language of this country and they will be encouraged to acquire it, but to deny them citizenship until they acquire it is being ridiculous. It is also being discriminatory between those who have a background of education in many languages and those who have a background of education in a few languages or knowledge only of their home language.

Migrant women especially should benefit from this amendment when they apply for citizenship. Due to family and employment responsibilities migrant women often find it harder to attend English classes in order to gain what is referred to in the existing Act as adequate levels of their newfound language. The Government understands that to participate fully in Australia's social, cultural and political life, a fair knowledge of English is essential but it does not want to deter those with limited English from taking out citizenship. The amendments will provide for the repeal of the definition of British subject status from the Citizenship Act. Australia is now the only country in the world that continues to use the concept of British subject status in preference to its own nationality. All other Commonwealth countries, including Britain, have abandoned this notion. It should be emphasised that changes relating to the British subject status derive from the need to provide equality to all migrant groups residing in Australia. Overseas developments and changes occurring within our society since 1949 give credence to such changes.

It has already been mentioned that this Bill is the outcome of a most far- reaching review of the existing Citizenship Act. Proposals to vary the Act were announced in May 1982-proposals which had already been scrutinised by various ministerial advisory bodies and by State governments. They were widely circulated throughout Australia to community groups and were also the subject of discussion at public forums in every capital city during June and July 1982. Written submissions and informed talks were also part of the process of extensive consideration of the Act. The views put forward during these national consultations were summarised in a report. The then Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the Hon. John Hodges, said at the front at the report:

The following report attempts faithfully to capture the sense of the wide range of opinions expressed during the consultations and to present those views in a manner that will be informative to the general public and of assistance to decision-makers.

Careful consideration of that report in preparing this Bill has also been given to suggestions from the Human Rights Commission, which undertook a very thorough review of the Citizenship Act in 1981-82. Of course, the Government's own policy commitments have been included in the Bill. The amendments under discussion at this time clearly embody our policy, which states:

Labor considers that the Australian Citizenship Act of 1948 is in urgent need of reform. The current Act contains many anomalies and discrimination on the grounds of sex, ethnic origin and nationality. All discrimination should be removed . . . Act as quickly as possible. This would include the requirement that an applicant demonstrate an adequate knowledge of the English language.

Labor also questions the appropriateness of the 'Oath of Allegiance' as it is currently worded. Many ethnic and native-borne Australians are dissatisfied with the wording of the oath. Labor would initiate a study to be carried out which would investigate possible alternatives to the present oath . . .

The oath of allegiance segment of this Bill has caused much community discussion, not to mention hullabaloo in the House, over past months. Very strong support was conveyed at the national consultation level for a rewording of the oath to carry with it a distinctly Australian flavour. I fail to understand why having an Australian oath or pledge of allegiance is such a criminal offence. I, as a fifth generation Australian, believe that it is our country to which we have allegiance in the first instance. It became evident that the swearing of allegiance to a monarch residing outside Australia was very confusing to prospective citizens. It has been confusing for a very long time. It certainly confused my husband when he took the oath of allegiance some 32 years ago. It goes without saying that the declaration of allegiance is of great importance to the person about to embark on Australian citizenship.

In speaking to this Bill I am adding my support to what I hope will soon be one of the finest achievements of this Government and the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. It is legislation that will be of positive benefit to newcomers to our nation and encourage them to take up their new lives in an atmosphere of national pride and identity-a national pride and identity which I share in this great country of ours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West), in his second reading speech, used the word 'discrimination' and derivations of it to justify parts of this legislation. Discrimination is one of the buzz words of members of the Australian Labor Party and must rank with reform as part of the meaningless rhetoric in which they indulge themselves from time to time. The Labor Party, as with my Party, discriminates. I would like to think it is discriminating as to who may be endorsed as a candidate for political office. Certainly the Labor Party discriminates as to who will belong to which faction, whether it is the right wing, the left wing or the putrefaction. I would just like to question why we have to go through this charade of justifying--
—Order! Though we are having a far-ranging debate on this Bill, it would be appropriate if the honourable member did not range as far as he appears to be intending to do.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I should explain to you that I am responding to the use of the word 'discrimination' to justify part of the legislation, as you will find lavished throughout the Minister's second reading speech as recorded in Hansard. I question why we have to go through this charade of justifying what are the Government's priorities instead of claiming it is the elimination of discrimination. It is a fact that immigration and citizenship laws and policies already discriminate in favour of refugees, family reunion, those possessing skills in demand and those with employment-creating capital to bring with them, and rightly so. I presume that this Government and future governments will expand or contract those qualifications as economic and social factors change over the coming years. In fact, it is the right of any government or any nation to discriminate. When we use that word unwisely and selectively we bring it into disrepute and we tend to mislead.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to think that we will not try to kid the nation that there are not legitimate forms of discrimination enshrined in these amendments as well as in immigration and other laws as they presently stand. Discrimination will remain in the principal Act after these amendments are passed. It is time to discredit the use of the word 'discrimination' in the way in which it is used in political debate. We should not accept the implied meanings given by the radicals, including this Minister, without question. Despite its collectivist approach to social and other problems, this Government must not be allowed to explain away parts of these amendments on the spurious basis that they eliminate all, or even some, forms of discrimination. Nowhere in the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill is discrimination more evident than where it seeks to relegate, in clause 12, the oath of allegiance to second place after, and only as an alternative to, an affirmation.

The complexion of Australia and its people has not changed that much since the election of the Hawke Government to justify relegation of the option to swear by Almighty God to a mere second choice. As my colleague the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) has already indicated, polls in Australia show that a vast majority of citizens believe in a god and although some of those believers do not choose to take the oath when required, my attendance at citizenship ceremonies in my State leads me to observe that the majority still prefer to swear by Almighty God. It is insensitive in the extreme of the Minister to impose his values on a great many others, probably a great majority, in this way . Similarly, the omission of direct reference to the monarch in either the oath or affirmation seems to bear the personal stamp of the Minister and a gaggle of Australian Labor Party members who will seek to change traditional values in Australia for the sake of change.

Queen Elizabeth the Second remains Queen of Australia. Despite the preferences of many honourable members in the Government Party, she will remain Queen of Australia whether they like it or not. The reference in the present oath or affirmation which calls on new citizens to 'be faithful and bear true allegiance to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth the Second, Her heirs and successors' recognises the monarchy and her constitutional role. By omitting reference to the monarch and substituting the pledge to uphold the Constitution, these amendments promise to offend many new and old citizens alike.

It will be argued that since upholding the Constitution necessarily involves supporting the monarchy-at least until Labor's republican plans have progressed- the new form of words makes no substantial difference. This is the type of casuistry we can expect from the Minister. Symbolically-symbolism is at the heart of matters such as this-the new wording does matter and the omission of any reference to our Head of State is ominous, to say the least. Next on the list, no doubt, is the Australian flag. In that regard I must say that it is surprising that a front runner for its replacement seems to be the Eureka flag, the symbol of a group of mining entrepreneurs and tax evaders, the last people whom I understood these socialist parties would be ready to support. The Minister, in his second reading speech, refers to the declaration of allegiance and how it is regarded as of singular importance by many people. Of course, he is dead right. He offers, as part justification for making mention of that reasoning, strong support 'for wording distinctly Australian in character'. The new affirmation reads:

I renounce any current citizenship and all allegiance to any state other than Australia. I pledge that I will faithfully uphold the Constitution, obey the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.

What could be more Australian than the wording in the present oath where it refers to the Queen of Australia? Surely that is Australian. Surely that is traditionally, and in the most accepted way, Australian. The honourable member for Tangney (Mr Gear) who attempts to interject is a member of another faction. He, along with a few new members here, belongs to the watermelon faction. They are green on the outside and various shades of red on the inside.

I conclude by saying that there is much in the Bill to support. I think there is much in the Bill with which we hold great truck also. That has been mentioned at length by my colleague the honourable member for Denison. Not without great reservations we intend to go along with reducing the qualifying period for Australian citizenship from three years to two years. While I say 'not without great reservations' I take the point that, in most other countries, the term for qualifying for citizenship is much greater. I see great merit in it remaining at least three years. However, I do not think it is one that we intend to go to the barricades on. We support amendments which give right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal against the Minister's decision to deny or deprive Australian citizenship in certain circumstances. I support the exemption of elderly applicants from the requirement to have a basic knowledge of English, although I am opposed to a reduction in the requirement of knowledge of English as an adequate basis for those who are younger.

We add our support to changes to renunciation of allegiance and removal of discrimination certainly on the basis of sex and marital status. Deprivation of citizenship when obtained by fraud, deceit and concealment of information or any other dishonest means should also certainly constitute disqualification from Australian citizenship. But in those areas, which have been outlined either by me or the shadow spokesman on this matter, the amendments cover our position. Those amendments will have my entire support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the chance to speak on the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1983 because Australia has been one of the few countries in the world that draw the majority of their citizens from other countries. Therefore, the Bill is very central to Australia's well-being.

SPEECH.PARA: In my contribution today I would like to review the role new citizens have played in the development of Australia, certainly since the end of the last war, and comment on where the amendments before us today will enhance the role of new citizens in Australia. First, I think it is true to say that most Australians do not know what it is like to go and live in another country. I would imagine that would be reflected in this chamber today. Not many of us have gone overseas and tried to live as new settlers in another country. I went to Canada in 1970 and, therefore, I can speak in a limited sense with a bit of empathy.

One of the first things that strike a person when he leaves his own country and goes to another country is that he is all on his own. He does not have any friends; he seldom has relatives. Under the current policy I am sure that the family reunification system is a good one because it brings out those people who have relatives in Australia and that is a tremendous help. But certainly a lot of people who have come to Australia did not know anybody when they got here. They certainly face handicaps, the major one being language.

When I went to Canada the people spoke English; so I was fairly well looked after in that regard. But many of the people who come to Australia do not have English as their first language and have a very limited use of English when they first get here. That has implications that not many of us would realise-simple things such as going to a doctor and telling him what is wrong in order to get an illness diagnosed. In a newspaper this morning there is a call for more ethnic doctors to be trained in Australia. The Vietnamese population of Adelaide is a good example. I think that is a good move because those people cannot speak to an Australian trained doctor with any sense of security. Obviously the language barrier would preclude them from getting the medical care to which they are entitled as residents of Australia. We take for granted simple things such as reading the morning's newspaper. Some of the larger ethnic groups produce newspapers, and they are good newspapers too, but they usually come out on a weekly basis. So if a person cannot read English he is limited in finding out what is going on. Finding out about citizenship and how to go about applying for it is a problem. I know that the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs puts out publications in many languages, but getting the message through on how to become an Australian citizen is one of the restrictions placed on those people who come to Australia from other countries. It has moved me in my particular area to produce what I call a citizenship information kit. I can publish that only in English. I will be putting that information out next month and making it available to any intending citizen, new citizen or, indeed, anybody who wants it in my electorate.

Once again I come back to the fact that I speak only one language. I suppose that is a deficiency, and one which I am sure is shared by many other members, in corresponding with constituents. I instance simple things such as making friends in a new country. One's ability to make friends is certainly restricted if one cannot converse. Even getting a driver's licence necessary to get a job may be difficult. I know that learning the customs and laws in a new country is difficult, from my experience in Canada. For example, simple things such as taxation laws are completely different. I was working as an electrician at the time and I found that industrial laws were very different in Canada. I notice that the technical and further education system here is currently mounting programs designed to overcome that deficiency by teaching new tradesmen who come to Australia the industrial and technical language they will need to survive on entering the work force.

I turn now to one of the chief benefits that new citizens bring to Australia- the educational and vocational skills they developed in their own countries. That is a cost we do not have to worry about because those people have developed their skills at a cost to their own country and they have brought their skills out to us. If we look at the economy of a country, its hidden assets are its human skills, and certainly Australia has been the beneficiary over the years of sufficient skills to allow us to reach the point we have today. Without the immigration policy that was set in train by the Chifley Government and carried on by successive governments after the Second World war, Australia's standard of living, indeed the development that we see today, could not have been achieved. I suppose that in a sense today we face the same sort of crisis as we faced in those days. We have to start rebuilding our economy, and I am sure that the people who are yet to come to this country will play an important part in doing just that.

I turn now to some parts of the Bill. The first and most contentious part, if we listen to the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), who spoke for 20 minutes on it, is the desire to change the pledge of Australian citizenship. We have a choice of two different forms of wording and I suppose the honourable member sees that as divisive. I do not see it as being particularly divisive myself. The proposed wording for the first form of the oath of allegiance states :

I . . . renounce any current citizenship and all allegiance to any State other than Australia. I pledge that I will faithfully uphold the Constitution, obey the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.
The alternative proposed pledge states:
I . . . renounce any current citizenship, and all allegiance to any State other than Australia. I swear by Almighty God--
and that is the change--
that I will faithfully uphold the Constitution, obey the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.

Given the propensity of the honourable member for Denison for looking at socialist countries, I thought I would have a look at another democratic country , the United States of America. I rang the American Embassy this morning to get the text of the American pledge. That pledge states:

I hereby declare, on oath, that I absolutely and entirely renounce and abjure all allegiance and fidelity to any foreign prince, potentate, state, or sovereignty, of whom or which I have heretofore been a subject or citizen; that I will support and defend the Constitution and laws of the United States against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the same; that I will bear arms on behalf of the United States when required by the law; or that I will perform non-combatant service in the armed forces of the United States when required by the law; or that I will perform work of national importance under civilian direction when required by the law; and that I take this obligation freely without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; so help me God.

Let us look at the comparisons we can draw between the American oath of allegiance and the proposed Australian oaths of allegiance. The similarities are that both provide for swearing to God for those people who put a premium on that . In Australia's case we offer a choice for those people who do not. Secondly, both pledge allegiance to the Constitution and laws of their countries. The similarity is quite pronounced there. Thirdly, neither swears allegiance to foreign monarchies, so a comparison can be drawn there also.

TALK.START.PARA: —That will go down very well in Tangney.
—Good, I hope it does, because I will be there for quite a while.
—That's what you think.

—That is what people said last time. They did not think I would win the seat last time, but here I am. I should like now to deal with some of the points raised by the honourable member for Denison, who went on for 20 minutes in a rather emotional burst about how the Government will lose the next election because of the change to the oath of allegiance. Let us look at some of the issues there. It has been pointed out to me that the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee) when he was Minister drew attention in May 1982 to the confusion caused to many settlers by the requirement to swear an oath of allegiance to a sovereign resident elsewhere-not living in Australia. He also drew attention to the resistance of many people to taking such an oath. I wonder how the honourable member for Denison would get on swearing an oath of allegiance to the Queen of Holland? It is quite possible, if we trace our history back, that that could have been the case. I wonder whether the honourable member would have jumped up today and said the same sorts of things.

SPEECH.PARA: Currently, there are 1.2 million residents of Australia who could become citizens. I wonder how many of them will become citizens now we have removed that part of the oath of allegiance? A number of United Kingdom citizens have questioned the swearing of allegiance to the Queen because they already owe their allegiance to Her Majesty as a person, if not in her role as sovereign of Australia. A number of United Kingdom citizens serving in the Australian Army who have applied to become Australian citizens have expressed strong feelings at the requirement again to pledge their allegiance to the Queen. A number have said they find the requirement offensive to their commission or to their original oath of allegiance on joining the Army. In some cases the wording of the current oath has resulted in misunderstandings, including the belief that renouncing all other allegiances means abandoning one's cultural heritage. The proposed wording of the new pledges makes clear that it is the citizenship and not the cultural heritage which is being renounced. The two forms of pledge proposed will allow all people, whatever their views on religion, and here they have a clear choice, to make a full commitment of allegiance to Australia. I support that fully. Our first allegiance is to Australia and not to a foreign monarchy.

TALK.START.PARA: —She is the Queen of Australia.
—And Gough Whitlam made her that too.

—That is right. That is another point I would like to come to. Honourable members opposite keep going back to 1973. In fact they go back further than that to when the Constitution was drawn up. This Government certainly does not believe that those documents have holy writ. We think that as times change so should our Constitution. In fact, if we look at the history of constitutional changes in Australia, there are two parties that have opposed almost every one of them, and their members sit on the other side of the House. It might be true to say that in 1973 the Whitlam Government brought in that legislation, but I am certain that if we went back far enough we would find that at one time the Labor Party said, when vehicles first came on to the road, that they should have a person in front of them holding a red flag. We do not hold that view today because we know it is outmoded.
—You still support the red flag, don't you? Put that one in Tangney and see how it goes.

—I support the Australian flag. The honourable member for Denison kept coming back to the Hawke socialist Government. One thing that can be said about the honourable member for Denison is that he is a man of the 1950s. That is the sort of rhetoric we used to hear then. He should ask members of the National Party-when they are in the chamber-what they did. They conducted a survey on what people thought a socialist was, and some of the answers would surprise the honourable member. A lot of people thought that a socialist was a tourist who was overseas all the time. Not many people on the other side of the House use the word 'socialist' any more.
—You just admitted to going overseas.

—Not as much as Mr Fraser when he was Prime Minister. The honourable member for Denison also talked about public opinion polls supporting the Opposition's stand on this. I do not know of any such poll but, if Mr Fraser is to be believed, there is only one poll that counts and that is the one on polling day. When we look at the polls that are coming out now, I am fairly sure which way the next one will go. The honourable member for Denison also talked about two classes of Australians. Really, that is going back to the days when Mr Fraser as Prime Minister tried to divide Australia. We seemed to have a cultural cringe in those days. We thought that Australians were not as good as anybody else. Going back even further to that other celebrated conservative Prime Minister who used to adore the Queen, I can see remnants of that attitude today in the honourable member for Denison.
—Thank you. That is a very great compliment. I appreciate it.

—I am glad that the honourable member takes it as such. I do not think that anybody who looked at this legislation objectively-certainly those people from the United Kingdom or from any other Commonwealth country-could ever suggest that we mean any disrespect to the Queen of England. This legislation reflects the fact that change is occurring in Australian society and that we as a nation-certainly since the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) became Prime Minister-are a lot more proud of our nation than we used to be. Nowadays we seem to think that we can do a lot better, that to be Australian is not inferior and that to buy an Australian product is the right thing to do. Advertisements on television certainly do not talk about European products any more. Most of them promote Australian products. I think that that nationalism is reflected in this Bill because we are taking out the oath of allegiance to that monarch who lives overseas.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. That is a most offensive statement. She is the Queen of Australia and the honourable member swore an oath of allegiance to her last year.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I am glad that the honourable member brought that up because it was a point I meant to cover. It is true that I swore that oath of allegiance but I could not have changed it until I had sworn it. I was not even a member of parliament until I swore it. Now we have the capacity to change it if we want to .
—The next step! It is foreshadowed, is it?

—If it comes up for debate I will think about it, but I think that there are more important items on the agenda such as unemployment and interest rates, areas in which we seem to be doing a lot better than the Opposition is doing in this debate. I would like to make a few points before I wind up. One of those points alludes to the many agencies throughout Australia which are helping to bridge the gap for the new citizens who come to Australia. I am talking about the Good Neighbour Council and the many church and service organisations which act as a bridge to allow the new settler to come into the country and to find his or her feet. I think that those organisations do a tremendous job. It is a job which costs governments nothing, but if it was not done I am sure that the people who come out here would not integrate as fast as they normally do.

SPEECH.PARA: I close my comments by congratulating the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West). He is a splendid Minister. In his short time in office he has shown that he has the interests of Australia at heart as well as the interests of new citizens and citizens yet to come to Australia. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1984, which is now before the House, represents a very significant move on the part of the Government to change the provisions which have hitherto conditioned the practices of our society. The Bill contains a number of measures of considerable merit and logic. Yet, notwithstanding the insistent protests of members of the Government that it carries the imprimatur of the society, there is ample evidence that our population has great apprehension about it. That suggestion might be dismissed. Possibly a parliamentarian on this side of the House would be the least effective advocate of that proposition. With that in mind I bring before the House a comment contained in an editorial of the Maryborough-Hervey Bay Chronicle. I maintain that Maryborough, Queensland, would fairly epitomise the character of broader Australia, and may be taken as a fine example of the attitudes of broader Australia. On 30 January the editor was moved to remark:

SPEECH.PARA: What the hell is going on inside Australia's department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, and who is making decisions that are having the effect of changing traditional policies in that area?

The latest edict to surface is one affecting the 'Big Brother' movement, which in 58 years has brought out to Australia under a most successful sponsorship program 12,000 migrants, mostly from Britain.

The Big Brother people have been advised that the special dispensation which has applied to them in that period has been halted by the Department without any explanation, and the minister, apparently under the thumb of his bureaucrats, has refused to discuss the matter with them.
The move certainly adds weight to the view of many in Australia that there is an anti-European, more particularly an anti-British, bias within the Department.
Some group somewhere within the department-probably under the guidance of Mr Al Grassby-seems hell-bent on forcing multi-culturalism on Australia without the approval of the electorate.
There is not the slightest doubt that the composition of Australian society is quietly changing as a result of immigration policies of recent years.
That is a broad statement. It links with another editorial in the Maryborough- Hervey Bay Chronicle in which the editor says:
For a party that rode into power under the banner of 'consensus' the Australian Labor Party is certainly a living contradiction.

Not content with the normal divisions within the community, involving capital and labour, conservation and industry and other seemingly permanent points of controversy, it has seen fit to promote a few of its own.

The pointless scrapping of the traditional Queen's Medal for the champion shot in the Australian Army, the move to change the oath of allegiance, the possibility of the scrapping of the Victoria Cross for gallantry, and moves to change the Australian flag are all pointers towards republicanism, and they are removing the nation's background and history.
None of those moves will do a thing towards improving the quality of life in the nation. All they will do is promote divisions in the community when unity is so essential.
Electors will note-and the Chronicle will remind them at the next federal elections-that none were highlighted during the last Federal election campaign.

These are genuine concerns. They lead one to ask why these measures, which will in many respects change or remove the tenets and forms which have sustained our society, are coming about. One looks for motivation. One senses in the shadows behind this matter the skeleton of apprehension. Why is it happening? I know of one who had more time to address himself to research this matter, to flesh out that skeleton of apprehension. What has been put to me has proved to be plausible and persuasive. I offer it to the House for its consideration. Motivation is the operative word. Where can we look for the seeds of such a motivation? Maybe it would be a good idea to think back to 1973 when the then Minister for Immigration, Al Grassby, as mentioned in the editorial of the Maryborough-Hervey Bay Chronicle, sought to remove the oath of allegiance to the Queen. Parliament in its wisdom rebuffed that proposition. But it was a seed. That same gentleman is still in good standing with the former honourable member for Maribyrnong, Moss Cass, and his group. The report of the Committee of Review of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs states:

The task of radically restructuring the earlier policies of migrant settlement fell to Al Grassby, the Minister for Immigration in the Labor Government of 1972 . His 1973 statement 'A Multicultural Society for the Future' still remains the original testament and manifesto of cultural pluralism and multiculturalism in Australia.

The seeds germinate. They go a little further and start to sprout. Where, perhaps, did Mr Grassby secure his motivation? Where did he get his ideas? Mr Grassby says that he got his Irish inspiration as did Padraig Pearse and Eamon De Valera, the two key figures of Irish republicanism in this century. Addressing the Irish Day seminar, Mr Grassby said:
I am proud to be one of the great number like Padraig Pearse, Eamon De Valera and Albert Dryer who drew their Irish inspiration from Irish mothers.
What does Pearse say in his book? He quotes Tone, who, in 1798--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. I am very reluctant to interrupt my good friend the honourable member for Wide Bay in his interesting dissertation about Irish history, but there are other matters to raise and other honourable members who wish to speak. He should be more relevant to the Bill before the House.
—There is no point of order. I am sure the honourable member for Wide Bay will return to the specific points of the Bill.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am addressing the question of motivation so that this Bill may be assessed in the light of the spirit that has brought it into the House now. The quotation attributed to Tone is:

SPEECH.PARA: To complete the work of Tone! . . .
And let us make no mistake as to what Tone sought to do, what it remains for us to do. We need not re-state our programme; Tone has stated it for us:
''To break the connection with England, the never-failing source of all our political evils, and to assert the independence of my country''-these were my objects.

They are the objects to which Mr Al Grassby clearly attaches himself. That is the underpinning of the measures that have come into this House, under the mantle of benign paternalism, to accommodate the expectations and ambitions of our society, which in no way can be proved. The honourable member for Denison ( Mr Hodgman) issued a challenge to the Government to conduct a referendum on this question, fully confident of what would result from it.

There is this notion of the English. It is shown throughout the Bill and, notwithstanding anything that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs ( Mr West) and members of the Government may say, it is very difficult for one to accept that the Bill has not been introduced substantially, in respect of those critical elements, because of a spleen, a resentment of things that have gone by ; things that are very much part of our history. They seek in this legislation to achieve a total divorcement from the connection with the Queen of Australia and to remove all elements of the Act as it presently exists which in their judgment should be construed as acts of sycophancy to a crown.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are trying to make us a banana republic.
—That is very true.
—Come back to Irish history. You are better at that, Clarrie.

—The honourable member for Lowe suggests that I address myself more directly to the Bill. Let us refer to the Bill. The Minister in his second reading speech claimed that this proposal-the proposal that conditions the Bill- was supported by the report entitled 'National Consultations on Multiculturalism and Citizenship'. Yet Professor Zubrzycki, who wrote the report on the consultations, made it clear that it was difficult to gauge the representativeness of the opinions expressed in the consultations. The professor stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It is difficult to gauge the representativeness of the various opinions expressed. Clearly, forums conducted in the capital cities could not cater for more than a token representation from rural areas or non-metropolitan regional centres, though attempts were made to encourage such representation.

So it is acknowledged that the conclusions have been arrived at by a relatively small sector of the community. The Minister in his second reading speech also implied quite clearly that the notion of common nationality in Britain for citizens of Commonwealth countries is obsolete. So that there will be no misunderstanding about it, the Minister stated:

The common code concept of uniting all Commonwealth countries under the umbrella of British nationality is no longer valid. All other Commonwealth countries, including Britain itself, have abandoned this notion. Australia is now the only country in the world to continue to use the concept of British subject status in preference to its own nationality.

This is grossly misleading. Australian citizens resident in the United Kingdom are not foreigners, despite limitations on entry to the United Kingdom. Citizens of Commonwealth countries resident in the United Kingdom are eligible to vote; eligible to stand for parliament; eligible to join almost all parts of the Civil Service, whether or not they are British citizens. If the Minister clearly misleads the House in one instance, what credibility can be given to his propositions throughout his speech that otherwise may have been persuasive in their reasonableness? The document, as a consequence, must become suspect. It adds fuel to the fires of apprehension and misgiving of those citizens in wider Australia who have not had the opportunity to express a view as to whether they want the essential character of this country changed. The point that I put simply challenges the credibility of the remarks made by the Minister in his second reading speech. The fact that he has misled the House-and I would not wish to attribute to him an intention so to do-must make the document somewhat suspect.

The suggestion that we reduce the requirement in respect of knowledge of English may arguably be not unreasonable in respect of certain cases on compassionate grounds. But what is the reality of it? We will grant citizenship to residents of this country, which will make them immediately responsible to discharge their citizenship by, for instance, serving on juries and voting. How can they be equipped to discharge those duties if they lack the ability to comprehend what is happening in this country?

There is a potential mischief in the requirement to vote-and on being granted citizenship they are required to vote at law-when they lack the capacity to educate themselves directly and personally on the issues confronting this nation . They become dependent on others who must make good the inadequacy and, therefore, they are not volunteering an expression of view that is a result of their own reasoning and their own understanding. They become simply an echo for the opinions and ambitions of others. I say to the Minister that we have seen this happen with our fellow Australian citizens, the Aborigines. A particular grouping of Aborigines, with all understanding, have been totally incapable of coming to an honest and objective conclusion about where their best interests lie in regard to voting. They have been totally dependent on best friends or advisers who, in many instances, have had no particular interest in the Aborigines' welfare but certainly have had a keen interest in the result of a ballot. So we create a citizen, and leave him lamentably ill-equipped to cope with the responsibilities he faces as a citizen. The citizens of Australia have a right to expect people to accept the requirements of their country. We do not have to apologise to any new settlers in this country for what we are; nor do we require them immediately to conform to the practices hitherto established in our country. The very successful post-World War II migration policy is clear proof of that situation. Some four million people have entered this country and, as a consequence, have changed the character of the Australian today. It has happened very innocently and in the best of worlds. Nobody was required to condition himself to be another; nobody was required to shed his culture; nobody was required to dress in khaki and a slouch hat and become an ocker. Our football heroes in Melbourne now bear exotic names which would have been anathema to Australians in 1935. They would have been shocked at the proposition that their football champions should be, in the jargon of the day, 'wogs' or 'wops'. But now these people are accepted and are lauded as champions, and that is good and wholesome. But now we seem committed to the propagation of multiculturalism, which is simply a euphemism for divisiveness.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is what?

—It is a euphemism for divisiveness. We should just let it be. Nobody is required to shed the characteristics which attach him to his place of origin. But if people come here to be Australian citizens we have the right to expect them to accept that very truth: That there are no first, second or third class citizens. There is one Australian citizenship status, and we should not be undermining that condition by accepting second or third class, or even different types, of Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: If people who come to live in this God-fearing country have a notion that that is antipathetic to their philosophies or attitudes, they can scarcely expect the Australian citizens to change just to accommodate their expectations. We are one country and one people regardless of origin-I am speaking now of Australian citizens-and we should not undermine the status of that classification. It could well be reasonable to suggest that we have a post-qualification period; that we give people Australian citizenship in two years but make it conditional on their remaining for all practical purposes as residents for a further three years. SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill covers a variety of matters and I believe it is of considerable importance to Australians, particularly those in an area such as Lowe where one-third of the population was born overseas. This is not uncommon in the city seats and is not uncommon in some rural areas. Several points in the second reading speech of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) quite interested me. Firstly, I refer to his statement that prior to 26 January 1949 there was no such thing as Australian citizenship. (Quorum formed) It is a shame that all of my colleagues were not here to hear the outrageous racist remarks of the honourable member for Wide Bay, his appalling attack on Al Grassby and his support for that disgusting rag, the Maryborough-Hervey Bay Chronicle, which should go down in the annals of this nation as the nastiest newspaper in the whole of this country. I am sure that honourable members would like me to repeat my remarks on Irish history, but I will restrict the rest of my remarks to the Bill.

The Australian Constitution has a requirement in placitum (i) of section 44 which disqualifies from membership of Parliament any person who is a citizen of a land other than Australia. It is my belief that this may well exclude British citizens, United Kingdom nationals, Irish citizens and citizens of other British Commonwealth nations from membership of this Parliament. The legislation before the House today again reminds us that since the earliest time there has been an opportunity for aliens to become Australian citizens.

The point about the Bill raising most interest in this House is the pledge of citizenship which is to be either sworn or affirmed. The Australian nation has accepted more migrants per capita since the last war than any other country except Israel. We have a multicultural society, whether or not the honourable member for Wide Bay likes it. There has always been the right to affirm rather than swear the oath, going back to the days of Bradlaugh in the House of Commons . Many of us have sat through long, drawn out citizenship ceremonies in our areas. The new citizen, having taken the oath, the affirmation or, in future, the pledge, will have the same rights as any other Australian; and no government has any right to deport these citizens unless he or she obtained citizenship by fraud. Nothing can be done to those new citizens that cannot be done to any other Australian. They are subject to the normal processes of law if they fail to observe their pledge.

It is very important that the pledge be simple and that it be acceptable to all people in Australia, whether born here or new citizens. As is the case with other honourable members who have spoken in the debate, I have approached or been approached by United Kingdom nationals and asked them or been asked by them about becoming Australian citizens. On several occasions these people have said: 'I have already sworn allegiance to the Queen. I am already loyal to the Queen. Why should I swear another oath of allegiance?' What comes out of any independent examination of Australian society is that there are 1.2 million people who are non-citizens, who are residentially qualified for citizenship but who have never become Australians. Some of these people identified their reasons for not becoming citizens when consultations were held at great expense in every city by the previous Government. Some of them said that they objected to the form of pledge. They were people who may not have been British subjects but who for one reason or another had never come forward and gone to the trouble of becoming citizens.

The Government is proposing to introduce a number of quite important matters in this Bill. There is the proposal to repeal British subject status. There is the important proposal to reduce the qualifying time for citizenship from three years to two years. I feel that that is a quite progressive move because I have met many people who have come to live in my constituency and who, due to a death overseas or the illness of parents, have been called back to their former country to care for an aged relative. These people have had great difficulty in obtaining citizenship and in some cases were unable to obtain citizenship. Recently I was approached by a Polish national who was to be involved in the Australian Olympic team through a local rowing club. This man was not qualified for citizenship because he had been in Australia for only 18 months. I think he actually resided in another constituency. Despite the eagerness of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, he was not able to help in any way because the man had not qualified for citizenship.

I draw the attention of the House to some other important matters in the Bill. One is the requirement that the knowledge of English shall be basic rather than adequate. It is my experience that women particularly are discriminated against under the existing legislation. If a man and wife go for an interview and can convince the citizenship officer that between them they understand or can speak English, they can both become citizens. If a single, divorced, separated or widowed woman goes for an interview and cannot speak English-she may work in a factory where all her workmates speak another language-that woman cannot become a citizen. Citizenship is conferred on a family basis and it discriminates against sole women. I was approached by a woman who worked in a government clothing factory. She had to become an Australian to qualify for superannuation. This woman could not pass the English language test, yet she could come and see me on a Saturday morning at my interviews and in her basic English could tell me what was happening. She showed me the letter rejecting her citizenship application. She could not answer the questions, which perhaps were not tricky questions. They included questions such as: 'Who is the Prime Minister?' At that time who wanted to know who was the Prime Minister? This was some years ago.

Anyway, there is to be a really significant change. In some communities there was quite notorious and blatant coaching in how to get through the citizenship test in the knowledge that certain questions would be asked. The Human Rights Commission looked at this issue of basic or adequate English. It is important to recognise that not every person who was brought here after the war as an adult earlier had the opportunity to go to school. In some countries there was no education because of poverty, depression, war or famine. I have often met in my office people who could not sign their names on a pension form or on an application for a Housing Commission house and who could not speak English. Yet such people are here, have been working here and have been contributing to this country. They have children and, in many cases, grandchildren who are good Australians. They should not be denied the right to vote and the right to be full citizens. I am delighted that the age barrier is to be reduced from 60 to 50 so that an old couple who may never speak English can obtain citizenship after a shorter qualifying period. Many of us have no skill at learning a foreign language. It is a gift that some people have and other people have no capacity for.

Other important provisions in the legislation deal with adoption, which is becoming a very significant matter with the large number of Australians adopting children overseas and bringing their kiddies back here. There is also an attempt to make the legislation impartial in that there will be a right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. There are provisions in the legislation dealing with the loss and re-acquisition of citizenship. I have raised in this House the problem of women who have married foreign nationals and gone to live in other countries. They have taken out citizenship in those countries in the belief that they were still Australians. Now in two cases brought to my attention the mother or surviving aged parent needs their attention here and they cannot come back. In one case the wife became a British national and cannot return except under a normal family reunion sponsorship. In another case a young girl from my own suburb is now living in Canada, finds herself Canadian and cannot return. There is a need to cover these cases because people are not really sure what the position is if they take out the citizenship of their husband or wife. It is even more tragic if the marriage breaks up and they find they cannot come back to their home in Australia where their families are, reassume their former citizenship and have the right to live here.

I will not deal with other provisions of the Bill, but I will touch on this very unfortunate and silly amendment proposed by the Opposition. The Opposition has not the courage to oppose the Bill at the second reading stage but it has put up a very foolish amendment. The Opposition is totally without any knowledge of the law. The Queen is still to be legally the Queen of Australia. That is part of our Constitution. No matter what the Opposition says in its amendment, the Queen is part of the constitutional law of Australia. The notion that Australia is devaluing the importance and the honour of Australian citizenship is also rubbish, because it was the Liberal Government that took so long to grant citizenship applications. It took up to a year. There were always long lists of people who, for very vague political reasons, were not granted citizenship. They were here as permanent residents. They were denied citizenship . They had no right to come and go as they pleased. They were people in a very difficult situation. Having accepted the person into Australia and approved his or her permanent residency, there is an obligation, I believe, to grant him or her citizenship. I believe that what occurred previously offended against all basic principles of human rights. One cannot leave large numbers of people in this hiatus.

The third part of the Opposition's amendment is even sillier. It talks about the Bill being the forerunner of republicanism. That is quite offensive. It used to be popular once to call members of the Labor Party communists. Now the kicking of the communist can has gone out of fashion. We are now called republicans. If Australia had been a republic in 1975, one of the Liberal Party or National Party politicians of the day might have become president of our large and great nation. I shudder at the thought of this country ever becoming a republic. I am quite happy with the present constitutional provisions. I feel that Her Majesty the Queen will not lose any sleep tonight or at any time if this legislation goes through. I have the highest regard for the royal family. The Queen and her family set a great example for the Australian people and for the people of the British Commonwealth of Nations. One member of the Opposition has quoted from a silly newspaper-the Maryborough-Hervey Bay Chronicle-and has tried to strengthen his argument by harking back to Ireland in 1798. This is the most disgraceful aspect of debate that I have heard today. I only hope that my good friend Al Grassby never reads the Hansard report.

—I was pointing out that during the post-war period, when this matter was looked at by the Committee of Review of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs-I should mention that the honourable member for Wide Bay ( Mr Millar) referred to that Committee of Review and tried to slant some comments arising from it-the Committee pointed out that there were three main thrusts in social policy in the post-war era. As all honourable members would know the first was assimilation. It was considered that, by and large, existing institutions were deemed adequate to meet migrant needs. Then it was realised that although the institutions were designed to meet migrant needs they did not do so. This was followed by the policy of integration. This has been well described by an expert in this field of migration as the 'melting pot ideology'; a blending of cultures to preserve the best of all worlds. The third policy-this is the one which the Australian Labor Party is prepared to support-was multiculturalism. This recognises the ethnic diversity in Australian society and the powerlessness of many migrants from non-English speaking countries. It is against this background that this Bill should be understood, not the restricted interpretation placed upon it by the honourable member for Wide Bay.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill that is before the House gives effect to the Government's commitment, firstly, to ensure that the Citizenship Act reflects the common national identity of all Australians. Secondly, it removes from the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 discrimination between persons on the basis of sex, marital status and national origin. Thirdly, it provides for reviews by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of decisions by the Department or the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to deny or deprive persons of citizenship under the Act. Fourthly, it amends the Act so that it will become thoroughly Australian in character.

This debate will have one important outcome to which the Bill does not refer: It will make known to the wider public that Australian citizenship did not exist before 26 January 1949. Those living in Australia before that date were either British subjects or aliens. The measures contained in this Bill will make it easier for those who wish to do so to become Australian citizens as soon as possible after settling in Australia as well as remove what many people see as the disincentives to acquiring Australian citizenship contained in the present Act.

It is pleasing to observe the increase in the number of persons who have been taking out citizenship in recent years. In 1981-82, 78,000 people took out Australian citizenship; in 1982-83 this rose to 101,000 people and it is anticipated that there will be a similar rate of increase this year. My observations at a number of naturalisation ceremonies held at Wanneroo and other places in my electorate are that those people seeking citizenship do so because they have a pride in Australia and a willingness to work for its prosperity.

There has been a continuous process of review of the Citizenship Act over the last two or three years. It should be noted that the former Government took part in that review. Credit should be given to that Government. On 6 May 1982 the Minister concerned announced a number of proposed amendments which had already been the subject of close consideration by ministerial advisory bodies and by State governments. These proposals were widely circulated throughout Australia in 1982 to community organisations and were discussed at public forums in every capital city in June and July 1982. There were also supplementary inputs from written submissions and informal talks.

Credit must be given to Professor Zubrzycki, the Chairman of the Ethnic Affairs Task Force, for the thoroughness with which he attempted to obtain the views of community organisations. In a covering letter in the report entitled 'National Consultations on Multiculturalism and Citizenship', which was published in October 1982, he stated:

I was an active participant in the public forums and in addition spoke with several hundred community leaders, representatives of the media and ordinary citizens. I became a target of some criticism, mainly from the representatives of those groups in the community that would favour a return to a discriminatory immigration policy and those who are offended by the suggestion that multiculturalism is for all Australians and not just an indulgence to be extended to immigrants until they adapt to a homogeneous society.
He went on to say:

The experience of national consultations has reinforced my belief that a vision of a multicultural Australia and its present foundation in the existing range of policies and programs is the one viable option which must be pursued if we are to avoid the communal disorders that have plagued other pluralistic countries. A return to the policy of assimilation would not be in Australia's best interests today. It would make us poorer in that we would be denied the benefits of cultural diversity. It would perpetuate those structural conditions that place many members of our cultural minorities at an economic disadvantage.
Finally, he stated:
I firmly believe that a common language and commitment to democratic institutions, the rule of law and an Australian nationhood will remain a strong bond to hold our society together.

I suggest that this Bill reflects the views put at the national consultations, as well as the amendments which were suggested by the Human Rights Commission. Let me now turn to the topic which has caused considerable community discussion; that is, the declaration or pledge of allegiance. From listening to some of the speakers opposite, including the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), the honourable member for Denison and the honourable member for Wide Bay, one could be forgiven for believing that this is an horrendous measure. It is not. The pledge incorporates three separate but important elements: Firstly, the renunciation of former allegiance; secondly, the commitment to observe the laws of Australia; and thirdly, a declaration of new allegiance to Australia. That there are two forms of pledge indicates the Government's awareness that many people wish to swear an oath before God when giving allegiance to Australia. The pledge, in either form, can be said to be distinctly Australian in character. Its phraseology expresses full commitment to Australia, its laws and its Constitution. The present renunciation of allegiance appears to be ambiguous. It does not make it clear whether people are being asked to renounce their previous nationality, their previous language and culture, or all three. The proposed wording of the renunciation makes it clear that only allegiance as a citizen to one's former country is being renounced. I would say that this is supported by all ethnic groups within the community.

I welcome the proposal to reduce the residence eligibility period from three years in the previous eight years to two years in the previous five years. This proposal recognises that many migrants genuinely wish to become Australian citizens and assume the associated rights and responsibilities relatively soon after settling in Australia. To wait three years can be a source of frustration. I also welcome the proposal to give the Administrative Appeals Tribunal powers to review and determine decisions to deny or deprive persons of citizenship. This is consistent with modern principles of judicial review of administrative decisions. We are a multicultural country. This Bill will improve the existing Citizenship Act by taking account of that fact. I support the Bill.
