SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I am delighted to see you in the chair for this important debate. The debate on the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill is one of the most significant that has taken place in the House because it affects the whole gamut of Australian life and the attitudes of Australian people. I have endeavoured in my examination of the proposals that are before the House to make some sort of assessment by the study of law and history to see what is entailed in the processes of citizenship. I believe that if one looks at the history of citizenship one ultimately comes to the position of accepting that a man cannot abjure his native country or allegiance which he owes to his sovereign. He cannot divorce himself from that position. That is our starting point. I believe that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) and all honourable members would agree with that proposition. We heard debate early in the evening about the position of the sovereign. I will not raise the position of the sovereign until later in my comments. We will accept for the word 'sovereign', 'country', 'constitution' or the wide gamut of descriptions that are used to encompass what is meant in the word 'sovereign' I have used.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe there are two aspects of citizenship in civilised countries that are ascribed to an individual. These are two distinct legal conditions which apply to that individual on attaining citizenship. One is by virtue of his becoming the subject of some particular country binding him by the tie of natural allegiance and which may be called his political status. He is placed in society as a political entity.

The other aspect is by virtue of his having ascribed to him the character of a citizen of some particular country. As such, he is possessed of certain rights and subject to certain obligations. This is the aspect of the character of a citizen. On one hand, we have the political status of a person and on the other hand we have the character of a citizen-what a citizen really constitutes as an entity within our community. These are the two aspects I believe we need to consider when looking at citizenship.

The Minister and the Government have canvassed the views of citizens or those who may become citizens in regard to citizenship. I do not believe that the Minister or the Government has in fact canvassed the aspects of the political status and character of a citizen that I have raised. I believe that all Australians who are citizens have a view on the character of citizenship. They were not consulted in the processes which the Minister went through before preparing changes to the legislation. In fact, the previous Government did not have an opportunity to pursue the matter to its fullest extent, which I believe would have taken into account the need to consult all Australian citizens to the best extent possible on what they believe the character of a citizen is. I believe the Minister and the Government have successfully pursued the political status of a citizen but have not been able to apply the other aspect of citizenship-the character of a citizen-in the changes they have made to the legislation.

The House will be aware that we have had some debate about the role of the sovereign. In my pursuit of this matter I have turned to various laws and provisions that other countries have adopted in order to establish citizenship for their people. First of all I will refer the House to the requirements of the oath of allegiance-not a pledge-of Malta, a country with a strong socialist government. I read the oath that people take when becoming citizens of Malta. There are various oaths for those who become, for example, the Prime Minister or the President. However, the oath for the citizen is:
I-
giving the name of the person-
solemnly swear or affirm-
the choice is there of oath or affirmation-
that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the people and the Republic of Malta and its Constitution. (So help me God).
That is the conclusion for those people who take the oath. I draw the attention of the House to the difference between the Maltese oath and the pledge that is proposed by the Government which states:
I . . . renounce any current citizenship and all allegiance to any State other than Australia.
That is the first sentence of the pledge which is then followed by the part that compares with the Maltese oath. It states:
I pledge that I will faithfully uphold the Constitution, obey the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.

The Maltese oath is somewhat stronger. Instead of saying, 'will faithfully uphold', the taking of Maltese citizenship requires the person to say, 'I will bear true faith and allegiance'. There are no inhibitions to that statement; there is no holding back. There is no 'upholding faithfully' which is a somewhat more qualified statement than that which the Maltese citizen makes. That concerns me. Whilst this may be, as the Minister described it, an Australian- style oath or pledge it lacks strength and commitment. The people of Malta pledge true faith and allegiance. A strong and unequivocal commitment is prominent in the oath of that strongly socialist country Malta.

I turn to another country of a similar political persuasion-Greece. I will read to the House the form of oath that is taken by Greeks. I know my friend the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) will be familiar with this. This again is in the form of an oath-not a pledge or qualified statement, but an oath . Can anybody doubt the strong historic tie of the Hellenic tradition, a nation that has its citizens scattered around the world, many of them in Australia? As Greek citizens they take a strong oath and make a strong commitment as individuals to the Hellenic tradition. It is not a pledge. It is a strong commitment by the individual who states:
I swear-
there is no option of affirming-
to bear true oath to the Country and to observe the Constitution and laws of the State and discharge conscientiously my duties as a Greek citizen.

That is not some wishy-washy 'fulfil my duties as a citizen'. It is to ' discharge conscientiously my duties as a Greek citizen'. I hate to have to say to the Minister that he has the most wishy-washy pledge possible, and the most wishy-washy pledge of any country that I have examined. The Minister has discounted citizenship in this nation to the extent of not even having a pledge that is worth while.

I turn now to Britain. Honourable members might suspect what a British citizen would have to say in the circumstances of taking an oath or affirmation. I will deal with the oath because the affirmation is similar. Honourable members will understand where the variation of wording for the affirmation is. The oath states:
I-
giving the name-
swear by Almighty God that, on becoming a British citizen, I will be faithful and bear true allegiance to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth the Second Her Heirs and Successors according to law.

That oath is very simple and is understood by Australians and by those people who up to this point have become Australian citizens because it is very similar to our own oath of allegiance. I will not analyse the British oath because I think it will become clear to the House why we have adopted an oath similar to the British oath.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unequivocally.

—It is an unequivocal statement. There is no chance of avoiding the responsibility implied in the statement: 'I will be faithful and bear true allegiance . . . '. There is no chance of avoiding the responsibility, as there is under the oath: 'I will . . . fulfil my duties' or 'obey the laws' or 'uphold the Constitution'. The statement which the prospective British citizen makes states: 'I will be faithful and bear true allegiance . . .'.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the United States oath. I think that all honourable members are aware of the passionate feeling which citizens of the United States have for their citizenship. I have never met an American who is prepared to forsake his allegiance. When one reads the basis of the American oath one understands the very strong commitment which citizens of the United States make to their country . The oath states:

I hereby declare, on oath, that I absolutely and entirely renounce and abjure all allegiance and fidelity to any foreign prince, potentate, state or sovereign of whom or which I have heretofore been a subject or citizen . . .
That is the first part of the oath-the declaration and renunciation aspect. The second part states:

. . . that I will support and defend the Constitution and laws of the United States against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the same; that I will bear arms on behalf of the United States when required by the law; or that I will perform noncombatant services in the armed forces of the United States when required by the law; or that I will perform work of national importance under civilian direction when required by the law; and that I take this obligation freely without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; so help me God.

That oath of allegiance is sworn by people to gain citizenship of the United States. It is a long piece. Let us examine some aspects of what the Americans do to see whether there are any implications for us in Australia. First of all, the American oath states:
I . . . absolutely and entirely renounce and abjure all allegiance . . .
Our oath states:
I . . . renounce current citizenship and . . . allegiance.

There is nothing firm, nothing unequivocal, nothing absolute in our words. Yet the American oath says unequivocally that people must 'absolutely and entirely renounce' allegiance. That is a strong statement. It is meant to be strong, because people who become United States citizens are committing themselves unequivocally to that nation. Do we want Australians who are becoming citizens to have any lesser attitude? Do we want them to have an attitude which says: ' Well, I may have some reservations and I may not be absolute, but at this point of time I renounce any current citizenship'. Big deal! They are saying: 'All I will do is not have dual citizenship. I renounce current citizenship and allegiance'. The American oath says 'absolutely and entirely renounce'. There is no strength in what we are putting forward.
I turn now to the second duty which the new American citizen has to undertake. Under the oath he must state:
. . . I will support and defend the Constitution . . .

It is not 'I will faithfully uphold the Constitution', but 'I will support and defend' it. What about that for a positive and unrestricted statement of allegiance? There is no equivocation there either. It is positive, it is supportive, and it is constructive in action in support of the nation the new citizen has adopted. The third part of the oath states:
. . . I will support and defend the Constitution . . . against all enemies, foreign and domestic . . .

That involves the new citizen in a set of responsibilities within the nation. He or she takes upon himself or herself a responsibility for the nation as part of government for the people, by the people. The Minister has not understood this. He has not sought that sort of commitment from future Australian citizens. There is no 'for the people' or 'by the people'. What else does the proposal before us say? It says:
. . . will faithfully uphold . . . obey the laws . . . and fulfil my duties.

Honourable members should look at what other nations do. No other nation on earth has a commitment so futile and empty as the one we are putting through this chamber tonight. I say to the Minister that the commitment is futile and empty. Why does he not value Australian citizenship? Over the years since the Second World War hundreds of thousands of individuals have come to this nation under the migration program established by that great Labor man. He saw a vision , and said: 'Australia must have new citizens'. This Minister has backed away from that. He has said that we will discount that idea, that we will not really ask people to be citizens but only to give up what they feel at the moment, to move across a little bit, and then everything will be right.
There is no commitment in the proposition the Minister has put to the Australian people and to which he will be asking them to agree. The conclusion of the American oath of allegiance states:
I take this obligation freely without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; . . .

We know how many people have false passports, how many have made false declarations, how many have taken on citizenship because it has been discounted? It is now being discounted even more. There is no requirement to examine a person if he is unfaithful to his oath. If a person performs some traitorous or unwarranted act he cannot be asked: 'Did you take on this responsibility freely and without reservation or for purposes of evasion?' What do we say to them? We say: 'All you have to do is say that you will faithfully uphold the Constitution , obey the laws and fulfil your duties'. There is no real commitment. I am extremely disappointed in this House and particularly in the Government for not drawing out the responsibilities and sense of dignity which all Australians should have in being a citizen of this great country, a country we are seeking to build, and one which old Arthur Calwell sought to build also. The Government is walking away from the commitments he made to all people. The House needs to be aware that the oath, the commitment, the outward pledge by a person making his attestation or promise in a sincere, deep and responsible spirit must be a meaningful oath, a pledge which means something.

We have heard a lot about the Queen. If honourable members opposite cared to analyse what the Crown means in Australian law they would find, on analysis, that what the Queen does is to take up all aspects of the American oath of allegiance covering every detail of the administration of law, of defending the country, of being a good citizen, of having a citizenship character which can be identified. Honourable members opposite have not tried to find out what the Crown means at all. They have pushed the Crown out of the oath and have left nothing but barren words which are a half-hearted commitment to citizenship. If they are to remove reference to the Queen, let us have some definition of what the Crown stands for. The Ministers in this chamber understand the processes of the Crown. Those processes are the laws, the protection of the individual citizen, and the rights of that citizen. The Government has not replaced that with anything.

The proposal is half-baked and terrible. What the Minister and the Government should be doing is strengthening our citizenship laws so that it is harder for people to become Australian citizens and, being harder, there should be greater benefits for people acquiring it. Why not extend the period but give people social security benefits when they are citizens? Why not extend the period to three or five years and let them become full and proper citizens? The Government has not done that. The legislation that we are debating tonight is tokenism. A fellow can move in and out of this country, using Australia as his base, and the Government says: 'As long as over a two-year period you happen to have been here for a total of twelve months, you are an Australian citizen'. What is his commitment to this nation? It is a convenient base from which he can operate and his passport will not be questioned. Why does the Government not put some strength, some dedication and some commitment into citizenship, because that is what the new citizens of Australia value about this country. If we question any migrant group they will say that they value their citizenship. When we probe them deeply they say: 'This is the best thing we have done in our lives, for ourselves and for our children, and we are helping to build Australia'. Why does the Government think that they come out as they do on Australia Day? They love this country and they are committed to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill is very important but unfortunately the Opposition has concentrated almost exclusively on one small aspect of it to the exclusion of all others. Indeed, in some cases we have heard no mention of the major issues involved in all the questions surrounding citizenship which this Bill brings forward. I am extremely disappointed with the attitude of the Opposition and its failure to bring out those important aspects of the Bill. Responsibility for that lies with the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman). When we compare the honourable member for Denison with a former Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee), who initiated the modern discussions relating to the Citizenship Bill, we are comparing a nincompoop with an Einstein. Responsibility for lowering this debate on citizenship issues lies directly with the honourable member for Denison.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some of the history surrounding the development of this Bill. It was the honourable member for Balaclava, when the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs-not a Labor Minister-who made a statement to the House on 6 May 1982. He called for a bipartisan approach and put forward certain proposals about citizenship. He said: 'We will have discussions throughout the community all over Australia. After we go through that discussion process we will take all of the feedback from the ethnic community and from the Anglo-Australian community, from the totality of the Australian community, and we will put together citizenship proposals'. The current Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) has simply followed through that process. It is an absolute disgrace for the Opposition to raise in this House spurious arguments and attacks of a very personal nature against the Minister rather than focusing on the issues in the Bill.

In those discussions we had the participation of the then Opposition in the form of the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) who is here tonight to hear this important debate. He also went around Australia and had discussions with people about what they thought ought to be changed in the Australian Citizenship Act. I begin with one aspect of the report that has been debated over and over in this chamber. We have had debate about the oath of allegiance as if it were the only thing mentioned in the Bill and as if it were a concoction of the present Government. A report in October 1982 entitled ' National Consultations on Multiculturalism and Citizenship', was produced under the signature of the then Minister, Mr Hodges. The section of the report entitled 'Oath of Allegiance' states:
Speakers' responses dealt with two parts of the present Oath: the renunciation of former allegiance and the swearing of allegiance to Queen Elizabeth, her heirs and successors.

The strongly-held and predominant view emerging from the consultations was that swearing allegiance to a sovereign, and especially to a named sovereign resident elsewhere, was inappropriate in Australia at its present stage of history.

That is not a concoction of the Australian Labor Party. It appears in a document published when the present Opposition was in government and it was published as a result of the national consultations. So let us now put to rest completely the smears which the honourable member for Denison has been trying to put on the Labor Party around Australia in relation to this matter.

Let me also mention another point in relation to all the provisions of the Citizenship Act and the question of a mandate. We have had a lot of talk by members on the other side of the House about loyalty. What about loyalty to the Constitution in terms of the mandate given to a government to carry out its program? Is there any question that the Labor Party has a mandate to change the provisions of the Australian Citizenship Act? There is absolutely no question. It was talked about before the election. It was contained in the Party's platform and in the policy with which we went into the election. Having regard to the behaviour of the honourable member for Denison in this debate and his behaviour in relation to this specific matter and the ethnic communities, it is no wonder that the ethnic community organisations around Australia are calling for his resignation as Shadow Minister. He is displaying pathetic attitudes in relation to questions of fundamental importance such as this.

Let us look at these fundamental questions. The fundamental questions concern the basic rights of citizens. The most basic right of a person who comes to this country as a permanent resident is the general right to apply for citizenship and to be granted it unless extraordinary circumstances arise. Unless such extraordinary circumstances are raised, he should have that particular right. In the years before the first Labor Government of the modern era, the Whitlam Government in 1972, what did we have in this country? We had the misuse of the Australian Citizenship Act against the political opponents of the Liberal governments of that time. People were prevented from getting Australian citizenship on no other grounds than their political views. That situation continued until the election of the Whitlam Government in 1972. I know of examples when that occurred. Those people had the perfect right to become Australian citizens. It was only because of a kind of vicious behaviour on the part of certain Prime Ministers, who shall remain nameless, and their ministers for immigration that those persons were continuously rejected for many years. Some of those persons were trade union leaders. Because of the misuse of these provisions they were not allowed to become Australian citizens.

What else happened in relation to the Australian Citizenship Act? Whole groups in the community who were considered to be not too favourably disposed towards the various right wing extreme groups of the Liberal Party and so on were prevented from obtaining citizenship by the complete misuse of the English language provision in the legislation. Immigration officers were told: 'When you come across a particular bloke'-a wog or whatever description was applied to people in those days-'you must give him a very tough English test'. If they failed that English test, which even many ordinary Australians would have failed , they were not allowed to become citizens. That is the disgraceful situation which existed, and it is because of this that there is so much emotion about this issue in the ethnic community. The honourable member for Denison has no understanding of the fundamental feelings which so many people who came here as migrants have about the misuse of the provisions of the Citizenship Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —How did you get through?

—That is a typical comment. Let me tell the honourable member that I will match him in a test of English any time, and in logic as well, not to mention basic human values. I turn now to the period I mentioned, after the reactionary period when things were changed around by the Whitlam Government and it was made clear that further changes to the citizenship Act were needed. I give the honourable member for Balaclava his due; when he was the Minister he wanted to create consensus in this country on this important issue. One thing that can be said about him is that he understood the feelings of the ethnic community in relation to these matters. So the honourable member for Balaclava set up the consultative mechanism that I referred to earlier and through that mechanism a whole process of consultation took place. Today, we should be thanking the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs for bringing to fruition this process of consultation and we should have total bipartisan support for these proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: I will speak on something else which was referred to by honourable members opposite. It has been said that we are claiming that the only reason 1.2 million people have not taken out citizenship is the oath of allegiance to the Queen. We are not claiming that that is the only reason; that is one of several factors. Let me mention them.

TALK.START.PARA: —You hate the Queen, and she is married to a Greek.

—This is the level of interjection from the honourable member for Denison. He keeps saying that we hate the Queen. No, we do not hate the Queen; we simply love the Australian Constitution and the Australian people.
—No, you want to change the Constitution.
—What about the Queen?
—I see that some of the stooges are in here to try to interrupt.
—You have not answered your own question; what about the Queen?

—I will try to answer the question if the interjections from the other side will cease. Some of the other reasons why people were concerned about taking Australian citizenship had to do with this: Until recently there was no fundamental acceptance of the concept of multiculturalism, consequently people felt that they could not be Australian citizens and sustain substantial proportions of their culture. It was only with the carefully thought out proposals of the Minister-if honourable members opposite had bothered to read them they would have seen that he has thought them out carefully-that people are able to take an oath of allegiance covering all that is required for loyalty to this nation and to the Constitution while at the same time not discounting totally their previous cultures as if they were suddenly born again. The whole situation is this: Once multiculturalism increasingly becomes an accepted fact in this society more people will apply for citizenship because they will not feel that their identity, their heritage and so on, will be threatened by administrative fiat.

SPEECH.PARA: Other factors are important. Until we upgraded the family reunion program for migration people were concerned about taking out Australian citizenship because they did not know whether they would be able to bring their relatives to join them in Australia. That was a matter of considerable concern. When a person's brother or sister is living in a different place and that person does not know whether he or she will be able to come to Australia he will be careful about taking out Australian citizenship and finding that he loses the citizenship of his homeland. So what will that person do? He will try to secure a situation wherein he can have a family reunion and the family will therefore be in a position as a total group to apply for Australian citizenship. That is what is happening. If we read the facts and the statistics that the Minister has put forward we see that more and more permanent residents are applying to become Australian citizens.

There is another factor. I refer to what would happen if people felt at a certain age that they wanted to return to their homelands. That situation has been addressed only recently, again by the actions of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden). We are having bilateral negotiations with other countries in order to determine whether or not we can have arrangements for pensions, social security payments and so on so that persons who have a bicultural identity will not feel threatened if at a given time they feel that they want to take out Australian citizenship. All those factors are important, plus the oath of allegiance factor which I have already mentioned. I will not cover it again because everyone else seems to have spoken about it. I simply refer again to the report which clearly showed how many groups in the community were concerned about that, and the fact that the Government has acted on that concern.

Let me discuss a couple of other provisions of the Bill. I refer to the question of British subject status. We have been criticised for changing the British subject provisions. These were iniquitous provisions. For example, I came from Cyprus, a Commonwealth country, with my parents and they had the right to vote within six months of arrival. However, someone who came from the mainland of Greece had to wait for three years before being eligible. Some migrant groups were able to vote and participate within six months and others were able to do so after three years. That was because we had the provision that one did not have to be an Australian citizen to vote; all one had to be was a British subject. That, of course, is all outdated stuff from the Empire days and we want to get rid of it. It was the Labor Party which initiated the process for getting rid of those provisions and ending the discrimination.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were the beneficiary of an historical accident.

—Yes, it was purely an historical accident, as the Minister said. We brought in provisions to change that situation. Most people now, wherever they come from, are in the same category, under the same provisions, and are treated equally with respect to citizenship. They can vote only if they are Australian citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish also to discuss the English language provision. I have already referred to the way in which it was disgracefully used in the pre-1972 days to keep people from having Australian citizenship. SPEECH.PARA: With the presentation of the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill in December last year, the Australian Labor Government is ensuring that the Citizenship Act reflects the true multicultural character of Australia. The Bill ensures that the Citizenship Act reflects the common national identity of all Australians; removes from the Act discrimination between persons on the basic of sex, marital status and national origin; provides for reviews by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of decisions by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs or the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to deny or deprive persons of citizenship under the Act; and amends the Act so that it is thoroughly Australian in character. Honourable members will agree that obtaining citizenship is a necessary prerequisite for full participation of an individual in the total social and political fate of any democratic country. Citizenship entitles a person to vote and stand for public office, to be employed as a permanent public servant or judge, and to hold an Australian passport. it means eligibility to act as a juror as required, and to be eligible for military service as required. Citizenship confers both rights and duties.

If we look back in history we will see that post-war migration has brought some three million persons to settle in Australia. Forty per cent of my electorate is made up of people who were born overseas and I am proud to be their representative in this place. Fifty-six per cent of those three million new Australians are from non-British countries. As far as citizenship is concerned, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs consolidated statistics show that from the mid-1960s until the mid-1970s, when figures were maintained on registered aliens, over 500,000 persons, 70 per cent of whom were of southern European or Middle Eastern origin, were officially registered as resident aliens . By 1981 we estimated that 1.2 persons born overseas and aged 18 years or more were not Australian citizens. Sixty-six per cent of these persons were from the United Kingdom, New Zealand, United States of America and Canada and 33 per cent from other countries. At the same time, if one looks at the Department's 1981 citizenship estimates, one finds that comparatively few persons born in the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Canada an the United States have become Australian citizens. Around 25 per cent of those eligible, compared with 87 per cent Greek born, 88 per cent Polish born, 80 per cent Yugoslav and Lebanese born, and 72 per cent Italian born, have elected to take up citizenship.

This Bill has been presented to the House because the Government is committed to assisting all people, regardless of their national, linguistic or ethnic background. In Australia at present we have many hard-working residents who are not yet citizens and who consequently are not able to participate fully in all aspects of social and political life in our country. Evidence presented suggests that many of these persons are keen to take up citizenship.

SPEECH.PARA: If we examine the proposed amendment to the Citizenship Act we find that, amongst other things, the amending legislation proposes, firstly, to shorten the time for eligibility for a person residing in Australia from three continuous years to two continuous years of permanent residence, or from two years residence in total of the previous five years preceding application, compared to the previous stipulation of three years in the previous eight years. No one can say that that was fair-providing that the applicants meet the criteria of being of good character and having a basic knowledge of English. Secondly, the legislation repeals the definition of British subject status for Australian citizens, thereby making all permanent residents, regardless of British background, equal in the sense of citizenship entitlements. Thirdly, it will allow persons refused citizenship the right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and, fourthly, it will change the pledge of Australian citizenship to either one of two forms. The first form reads:

I . . . renounce any current citizenship and allegiance to any State other than Australia. I pledge that I will faithfully uphold the Constitution, obey the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.
The second forms reads:

I . . . renounce any current citizenship and allegiance to any State other than Australia. I swear by Almighty God that I will faithfully uphold the Constitution, obey the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.

With all the talk about God, Queen and country here tonight, I do not think I have ever had the privilege of being among so many people on the other side who, judging from the way in which they have treated people in the course of this debate, lack the basic Christian ethic. In relation to the first pledge, there is enough evidence, both from the Department's statistics and studies, and from other studies which have been undertaken, to show clearly people's increased commitment to take up Australian citizenship and enrol as voters. Given this commitment, anyone would agree that we should be allowing such people to participate fully in all aspects of our life. The shortened period for eligibility also meets the basic ideals of human rights. If people work, pay their taxes and meet the criteria of good character and a knowledge of the duties of Australian citizenship, they should be allowed to participate fully in all aspects of our society.

As for repealing the definition of British subject status, honourable members will agree that this amendment meets the commitments of other aspects of social policy in that all policy should aim to be non-discriminatory in terms of age, sex, birthplace, religion, et cetera. The change will mean that special emphasis will have to be placed on information and/or education strategies to inform people of British status backgrounds and to encourage them to take up Australian citizenship. In relation to the right of access to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, to which the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) referred, and about which he was interrupted so much, this is a very important amendment. Evidence has shown that many non-British ethnic communities in Australia believe that they are discriminated against when applying for citizenship. For example, in a research paper in 1974 Storer shows that between 1945 and 1970 635,555 persons were naturalised and there were 531 definite refusals on security grounds, 92 per cent were for being communists and 8 per cent for being right wing extremists. Of the 155 persons considered communists in the 1967-1970 period, some 53 were Greek, 35 Italian and 26 Yugoslav.

It might be argued that 531 refusals is a small number. However, this number was significant for it was often the case that those refused citizenship were the most active and articulate leaders of the growing vocal ethnic communities. As these persons tried to find out why citizenship was refused they soon ran into the brick walls of departmental secrecy. There were no grounds of appeal. These findings quickly spread throughout the ethnic communities. Consequently, whenever amnesties were announced in 1974, 1976 and 1980, many communities were quick to spread the rumour that such amnesties were political ploys by the conservatives to flush out left wing activists who would declare themselves and then find they had no guarantee of a system of appeal. The case of Ignazio Salemi, a left wing alien who applied in the 1976 amnesty and was subsequently deported by the government of the day-he believed it and it deported him-seems to verify such suspicions. All this has been described by Storer and Faulkner in a report to the International Labour Organisation on its survey of the 1980 amnesty. This study showed that most non-English speaking communities stated their suspicions and wanted a system of appeal.
As far as the fourth point is concerned, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West), in his second reading speech last year, clearly stated :

The present renunciation of allegiance is ambiguous and does not make it clear whether people are being asked to renounce their previous nationality, their previous language and culture, or all three. I believe it is important that the future wording of the renunciation makes it clear that it is only allegiance as a citizen to one's former State or country that is being renounced.

It is unfortunate that certain members of the Opposition have decided to make this a public issue. It is disgraceful that they have used this amendment in order to divide the community in the way in which they have. They have been led again by the honourable member for Denison who has been renounced by ethnic community groups all around this country. That will continue right up until the election. The honourable member for Denison should see me outside about the next election and we will have a wager with him. He is gone in Tasmania.

In some cases they have been supported; in some cases they have not.

The fifth initiative is the abolition of the automatic acquisition of Australian citizenship by British subjects resident in or with close connections with Australia in 1949. That is a controversial proposal. It will always be a controversial proposal when we are dealing with existing rights that people believe they have. Notwithstanding the desire, I think as much on the Opposition 's part as on the Government's part, to have a system of immigration and of citizenship which is not racially selective and which does not depend upon particular nationality as a test for eligibility, when seeking to remove certain privileges that some people have and regard as important we are dealing with a slightly different situation where some cognisance has to be given to these pre- existing circumstances.

Initiative six, the amendment to the oath of allegiance by deleting all reference to the Queen, is opposed by the Opposition. Initiative seven, the replacement of the affirmation of allegiance by a pledge, also by deleting reference to the Queen, is opposed by the Opposition. Initiative eight, the placement of the pledge as the first option rather than as an alternative or second option to the oath is another matter that the Opposition opposes.

In case I do not get time to come back to it, I make the point that it is my experience in my electorate, having attended many citizenship ceremonies, as I believe most honourable members would be very anxious to attend from time to time-I do not think there is anything unique about it-that the great bulk of applicants for Australian citizenship seek to take the oath; they do not seek to take the affirmation. The affirmation is there as a choice. The Government accepts that in the proposals it is putting to us. It wants to change the name to a pledge but, in essence, what it is saying is that the choice should still exist. The fact of the matter is that in a situation where applicants have an existing choice the great bulk of applicants seek to take the oath. It seems to me that if the great bulk of people seek to take the oath surely that is the appropriate form to be given priority. Surely it would be in the position of primacy in terms of an expression of view on that matter by the Government. I do not know why the Government would even entertain a change except that it is trying perhaps by that change to indicate some element of preference on its part . If it is not, I do not think the change is at all essential and the matter of the status quo could easily have remained.

Initiative nine is the removal of the reference to the Queen from the pledge. Initiative ten is the change of the renunication of allegiance and that matter has the support of the Opposition. The eleventh initiative is the removal of discrimination on the basis of sex and marital status. That has the support of the Opposition. Finally, the twelfth initiative is the deprivation of citizenship when obtained by fraud, deceit, concealment of information or any other dishonest means. That is supported by the Opposition. If my count is correct, of the 12 propositions that the Government has advanced it has the support of the Opposition in some five proposals. I think that is important and it is a point that has often been overlooked by members of the Government who have sought to discuss this matter.

In his second reading speech the Minister puts the matter in terms of an Australianisation test. I want to make it clear that I have a belief in an integrationist policy in relation to the way in which people come to Australia and are subsumed in our society. I do not believe we can assimilate people in any sense and compel people to fit into some particular niche, nor do I believe in a separate development policy. I think it is very important to note that the pursuit of multiculturalism as it is often termed, has not been pursued as a policy of separate development, nor do I think it ought to be taken to the point where it can be categorised as such. I believe that over time all people who settle in Australia will emerge as Australians. I think that that is appropriate and what one would expect in a society such as ours-one in which tolerance is a virtue.

It seems to me that the question of what is being an Australian or of Australianisation is a very subjective test. The Minister has applied his test, but in relation to those matters that are the subject of discussion in this legislation I must say that I do not understand how we can say, in relation to the language test that the Minister is proposing as a grant for Australian citizenship, that to have a basic knowledge as distinct from an adequate knowledge will in some way make it more Australian in terms of the test that we are applying. I do not really understand that. I do not see the distinction. I think the Minister has applied a test of Australianisation which is a subjective test and does not really bear out the changes he is making. I do not understand the way in which the changes to the oath or the affirmation of allegiance, as I have called it-the pledge, as the Minister wants to call it-in any way advance the cause of Australian nationalism. I really do not consider that those questions are at all relevant.

In the time that is available I turn briefly to the question of replacing the reference to the Queen in the oath of allegiance and the affirmation or pledge, as the Government prefers it. As a proposition I find it difficult to understand . What the Government seeks to do is to replace the reference to the Queen with a reference to the Australian Constitution. It may mean that some people who take that oath or make the pledge will not understand the full meaning of the oath or pledge they are being asked to undertake. The fact of the matter is that the change by the Government to the oath or affirmation will not, in one way or another, ultimately change Australia's Constitution.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you worried about then?

—I think it is misleading and inappropriate. Fundamentally, the reference to the Queen in the oath is symbolic of the type of constitutional monarchy that Australia has. The fact of the matter is that until the Government is prepared to change the fundamental nature of our Constitution, Australia is a constitutional monarchy. The fact of the matter is that this Parliament, within the framework of our Constitution, is juxtaposed directly with the Queen, who has a role as part of the framework of law making in Australia. Section 1 of the Constitution states:

SPEECH.PARA: The legislative power of the Commonwealth shall be vested in a Federal Parliament, which consists of the Queen, a Senate, and a House of Representatives, and which is hereinafter called 'The Parliament,' or 'The Parliament of the Commonwealth.'

The Queen's role is one of primacy in terms of her position under our Constitution. There is an established framework of law under which she operates as Queen of Australia. We are a constitutional monarchy. The Government can argue for a change but it should be honest enough to argue whether it thinks that Australia ought to be a republic so that people will know what the Government stands for. But Government supporters should not come in here asking for a change to the oath or affirmation of allegiance which seeks to put aside the fact that Australia is a constitutional monarchy by ignoring the fact that the Queen has a role.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not ignoring that at all.

—Of course the Government is. The fact that the Government is making the change obviously indicates some intention that people should read into the change. It may be legal and proper to take out the reference to the Queen and put in the words 'Constitution' but there is an indication of where the Government's priorities lie. That is the test. I do not believe it is appropriate to make that change without asking the Australian people for their view on this matter. The Government can do so by way of holding a referendum. I think that would be appropriate.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —The changes to the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 which are incorporated in the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill really are a true and clear reflection of community attitudes in Australia today . Those who care to dispute that really should take the time to consult the Zubrzycki report entitled 'National Consultations on Multiculturalism and Citizenship'. That report, as has been mentioned here, was commissioned by the former Liberal-National Party Government. I remind the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) that, as distinct from other reports, there was national consultation. The disaster of the return of the Liberal-National parties to government was clearly avoided and therefore the conclusions of the report can now become law in this country. Frankly, I cannot understand why the Opposition seems to be so offended by the Bill. The changes in this Bill represent a revaluation of the honour of Australian citizenship, not a devaluation. In regard to the residence requirement, if people spend two years in this country and are so significantly impressed that they take what I would consider to be a huge step and change their citizenship, I believe that we as a nation should feel honoured. What right do we have to deny it? Do we consider ourselves better than people born in other countries who wish to take Australian citizenship? The relaxation of the English language requirements from the definition of adequate to basic and the provision enabling those persons over 50 years of age to be exempted from the requirement is a humane recognition of the difficulty that some people have in picking up a new language. I am glad to see that the honourable member for Dundas has recognised that. In the case of other honourable members opposite that has not been the view expressed here tonight.

Members of the Opposition would do well to put themselves in the position of a migrant, especially an elderly migrant, coming to a foreign land. How many honourable members opposite could cope with a new language-in many cases a new alphabet-a new culture and new laws? How many members of this House can speak basically or adequately in another language? There would be very few. Does this detract in real terms from their real value as citizens? I do not think it does. Clearly the Opposition feels that it should detract from their rights as citizens. The honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) drew a red and white herring in the debate in expressing his fear that we would become bilingual like the Canadians. There is not one predominant non-English speaking group in Australia. There is no predominant language other than English in Australia. Last year we accepted people from more than 50 lands. I really feel the honourable member's contribution to this debate in that respect was meaningless.

Recently I was alarmed by statements from some Australians who I believe should know a hell of a lot better. These statements have served only to arouse racial intolerance, to seek racial scapegoats and to try to turn public opinion by raising the old fear and prejudice so prevalent years ago. What are these people all about? Some make pretences of racial tolerance. But one does not have to scratch too deeply to find that they are really espousing the thoughts of King O 'Malley, who said, during the white Australia debate:

We are here upon a continent set apart by the creator exclusively for a southern empire-for a southern nation-and it is our duty to preserve this island continent for all eternity to the white race, irrespective of where they might come from.

Anyone who listened to this debate today or who reads it in Hansard tomorrow would do well to reflect upon those words and upon recent Press statements and reports. The recent statements of Professor Blainey and the response statement of the shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), have certainly done nothing for racial harmony, to say the least. In fact the contribution of the Opposition to this Bill does nothing for racial harmony. There has been a clear distortion of the statistics and it is a sad distortion. The shadow Minister was asked by the interviewer on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation PM program on 20 March 1984:
What proof do you have that there is a bias against British and European immigrants?
The honourable member responded:

Oh well the figures of course speak for themselves. It's not very hard to prove the case when I simply say that in the last year, the year in which the Hawke Socialist Government has been in power, the number of British settler arrivals to Australia have been reduced by 33 per cent the number of European settler arrivals to Australia in the same period of time has been reduced by 22 per cent .

Those figures have been clearly misrepresented and misinterpreted. One would think that as the alternative Minister the honourable member would be aware enough to realise that it is not a direct manipulation of the Government's policy which produces those raw figures. It is a fact that major influxes over the past 10 years have come from non-European countries mainly in Asia. What we are seeing now is the natural response of any individual, that is, the desire to have his close family with him. It is not the reunion of the families of European migrants. That peaked long ago. Successive Australian governments have clearly and well realised their obligations to the refugees of the Vietnam war because of our role in creating that shocking war and the aftermath refugee problem.

It is about time the Opposition realised that, through the efforts of our fine Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) and our fine Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West), the Government is seeking to wind down the Asian refugee intake by finding solutions in the form of orderly rather than disorderly and illegal departure from Vietnam. It is because this Government has taken enlightened steps to develop dialogue with Vietnam that this can occur. But the Opposition wants it both ways. It wants us to avoid reasoned contact with Vietnam and it wants us to stop our Asian intake as well. But that only leaves many people floating around the Gulf of Thailand at the mercy of pirates and sharks.

Racial tolerance and harmony have developed in this country to a remarkable degree in the last 30 years. I remember during my time at school the racial intolerance which was shown towards European immigrants. The conservatives in this country have never been slow to bash even British migrants in their references to British unionists and the so-called British disease. It makes one ask: What are they all about? When all the camouflage of concern is stripped away we are left with some ugly Australians, Australians who rely upon their jingoism, racial slurs and an active resistance to the humanising of our migration and citizenship laws, Australians who under the charade of concern for racial harmony, make statements and inflame the immigration argument and activate unnecessary fears and deep-down insecurities, the bigotries and the biases of the ages which are deep down in all of us somewhere.

The Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill will bring the Australian citizenship legislation of 1948 well into the 1980s. It is well in line with the current attitudes of the Australian public. Although the words of King O'Malley may give warm inner glows to some people, they are rejected today by most Australians, despite the sad attempts of the 1984 King O'Malleys. This Bill is humane. It is reasoned and in touch with Australia's multiculturalism. One would expect it to be so. It has been put together by a humane, reasonable and in touch Minister. This Bill is committed to ending discrimination on the grounds of marital status , sex and present nationality. The changes to the pledge of citizenship proudly reflect our national identity, our integrity and our national autonomy. The qualifying period gives us the opportunity--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lusher Mr S.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was approached some weeks ago by Mr Peter Wilkinson, a producer from the 60 Minutes program, and asked whether I had an opinion on unemployment benefits. I said I had enormous sympathy for families surviving on the unemployment benefit, particularly in situations like Wollongong. However, I said I was concerned about abuse among those unemployed who were not prepared to accept work and I thought the benefit should not be so high that there was no incentive to get back into the work force.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Wilkinson said 60 Minutes saw value in producing a program which would canvass the problems of life on the unemployment benefit. Although such a program would be worth while, unless there was a focus that would raise the community awareness, people would see it as depressing and tend not to be interested. I saw a video-tape of a segment produced by the United Kingdom World in Action program in which a conservative member of parliament had lived on the unemployment benefit for two weeks. It was clear that the United Kingdom segment did not come to grips with the issues and dealt too much with the member of parliament himself.

I agreed that a program which more effectively exposed an Australian member of parliament to the unemployment environment could focus community attention on unemployment benefit problems. Such a program would provide an opportunity for the unemployed to put their case on national television. Equally, it would face up to the questions of abuse and incentive. My belief was that by eliminating the abuse that exists among those unemployed who put themselves outside the system, and who will not accept work, and who appeared to be getting along comfortably, we should be able to do more for the genuine work seekers and particularly those with families to support.

With that attitude in mind, and knowing that 60 Minutes would treat such a subject responsibly, I agreed to participate in the program. I accepted the challenge to move into an area of high youth unemployment, live on the single unemployment benefit, talk to people and see just what developed. In effect, I was prepared to throw myself in at the deep end. I was prepared to test my prejudice. And why would I not? Let me quote from an editorial in the Cootamundra Herald:

It's a poor reflection on society when a politician is criticised for being open enough to say what many people in the community have been saying in private for a long time: That some people in receipt of social service payment should ( and would) be working if it were not for the level of payment.
Stand up all those people who have never questioned in their own minds the level of dole to that element which is obviously flouting the system?

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. Do we have to sit here and listen to this hypocrisy from this person?
—Order! There is no point of order. I call the honourable member for Hume.
—The quotation continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Hands up those who do not know of at least one person who has given up or refused permanent work because 'it is not worth it' when compared with dole money and what they can make on the side?

Perhaps reflective of these widely held community views the platform of the National Party provides for payment of unemployment benefit to persons willing and able to work but genuinely unable to find unemployment. During most of my parliamentary life I have demonstrated concern with waste and abuse of public funds. I was a member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for six years. I have been a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure since its establishment in 1976. I was Chairman of that committee in the last Parliament, I am Vice-Chairman in this Parliament. I see the protection of taxpayers' funds as one of the principal responsibilities of a member of parliament. Why else is the Government unable to spend $1 of taxpayers' funds without specific authorisation from the Parliament and strict accountability to the Parliament?

Far from being a publicity stunt, my agreement to be involved with the program was based on an expectation of exposing abuse, and improving the lot of a needy section of the community by cracking down on those who are demonstrably not fair dinkum. At no stage have I, and for that matter, 60 Minutes, sought to trivialise this experience. The fact that so much attention has been focused on the production is the result of totally irresponsible media treatment of what has been, and will be seen to have been, a serious attempt to deal with a serious subject. Amongst other things, I have been variously accused of enjoying breakfast at a four star Canberra motel; attending a $35 dental appointment; being on the point of going to hospital; owning a flat in one of Canberra's better suburbs and visiting it; attending a plush business lunch at a major hotel in Canberra; comfortably furnishing my accommodation for the week; being paid by 60 Minutes for participating in the program; being censured by my National Party colleagues; running away from journalists; and having a bodyguard . Not one of these claims is correct. Individually they are not perhaps important, but taken together over the course of the week they have fuelled the media trivialisation.

In addition, a long series of inaccuracies about my personal lifestyle have been bandied about the media and some people who perhaps should have known better have been quick to climb on the bandwagon, expressing their views about something of which they were virtually totally ignorant. TALK.START.PARA: —It is always interesting to hear from the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch) on the subject of airports. It is a subject very dear to his heart. He thought he won the last election on his 'We will not do anything in Sydney' program. Immediately after the last election he took the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) into his electorate. He led him by the nose and had him ambushed. The honourable member said to us that the notion that one should do anything with Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport is discredited ; that it has been repudiated. Discredited by whom and repudiated by whom?

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member has given us some quite marvellous figures. He tells us that to build a third runway, if I heard him clearly, would cost $1.48 billion and that we could not get the fill anywhere in Australia to do this. On the other hand, if we were to get ourselves an area somewhere outside Sydney-we do not know where; only the Minister and the Government know-and if we were to set up a high speed rail system and, I suppose, a high speed road system, and if we built the airport there and moved Qantas Airways Ltd and the other internationals out there-that is all inherent in his proposal-it would cost a mere $800m. From where does he get those specious figures? I would like to see those figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the MANS Committee report.

—I would like to see those figures. There is no way in the world that he can sustain or justify those figures outside his electorate. He referred by interjection to the report of the Major Airport Needs of Sydney Committee. The MANS report made it perfectly plain that the logical thing to do was to extend Sydney Airport. What happened? As it came to the time when recommendations had to be made the State Government members dropped off that group, leaving only the Commonwealth Government members to make recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us have a look at the logic inherent in this marvellous parochial proposal which would relegate Sydney airport to a second-rate status. First of all we would have to dismantle the international carriers. Does the honourable member have any idea of the value of Qantas's investment? What would the honourable member do? Would he move Qantas? Would he move the international carriers? Would he move the major domestic carriers, the commuters and the whole lot? Does he have an answer? Does he have a view and has he thought it out? The answer is that the honourable member has not. Has he looked at Qantas's establishment at Sydney Airport? Has he thought of the vast cost it would take to move it, and who will interline? If one comes from Melbourne, for example, and goes to an airport which is an hour or an hour and a half outside Sydney, who will interline from that airport and what about the convenience?

The honourable member talks about his own area, about Kingsford-Smith, as though it were the only part of Sydney and the only part of the State that had any justification for consideration. The honourable member well knows that noise studies have demonstrated that aircraft these days are very much quieter. The honourable member well knows that the patterns of noise are such these days that with appropriate management and control of planes we will not have the kinds of problems to which he referred. If we establish a second airport it does not even penetrate his consciousness that we are doubling the problem; we are spreading the noise problem from one area, by Botany Bay, to two areas. It might have occurred to the honourable member that Botany Bay has water on one side of it whereas he wants to put an airport inland. If the airport is placed inland it means that we will have a noise problem for 360 degrees rather than for 180 degrees. Does the honourable member care about that? No, he does not. Where will he put this airport? Will he put it in the Blue Mountains, Bathurst or Canberra? Where else would he put it?
Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members will cease interjecting. It is impossible for Hansard to take a record.

—My apologies to Hansard, but the interjections, Madam Deputy Speaker , are at the best peripheral and at the worst inane. What will we do to the passengers? What will we do to the airlines? When will we make this decision? What will the cost be and what does the Minister really think? Somebody says: ' Put it in Launceston'. The Minister for Aviation breezed in here blithely to hear what the honourable member had to say, but he does not really believe in the proposal that the honourable member has put forward. The Minister is putting it off until after the next election. Does the honourable member know what will happen then? SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand Mr G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rooming houses have been an important form of accommodation in the Melbourne electorate for many years. The reason is clear. The inner urban communities have a social network to cater for the rooming house population. Although those needs are often minimal, they are not available in other suburbs. It would be ludicrous to suggest, for example, that the occupants of the Fitzroy rooming houses move to North Balwyn or like suburbs. Yet at the moment there is a crisis in rooming house accommodation in Melbourne and the number of rooming houses is declining dramatically. In the city of Melbourne apartment house accommodation has decreased by 50.4 per cent in the past five years. As at last December, there were 83 registered apartment houses with a capacity to accommodate 1,086 persons. In 1978 there were 164 registered apartment houses. The number of boarding houses, which are generally larger, has declined by 17.7 per cent in the same period, from 34 to 28. In Fitzroy the large rooming house stock has declined by about 50 per cent over the past 10 years and continues to fall at a rate of about 100 rooms a year. This is an alarming rate when one considers that, as the amount of accommodation decreases, the rooming house population has nowhere to go.

SPEECH.PARA: The reasons for the rapid loss are twofold: The age of the buildings and the spectacular inner urban residential valuation increases in recent years. The houses have reached the point where substantial spending is required to meet insurance, often fire requirements, and when this occurs owners find it more rewarding to sell on the open market. In most cases they are sold to private residents who renovate them for private use and they are lost to the most needy section of our community. As the stock is decreasing, our need for this type of accommodation is increasing. The economic climate has led to an increase in the number of people relying on inner urban rooming houses and their accompanying social networks. Today's rooming house client is not the stereotype older male often envisaged as a heavy drinking and dishevelled person. Today's client is the young, the single parent, the older woman and the middle-aged male. It is a spectrum of society that is suffering from a capitalist crisis.

Osborne House in Fitzroy claims that it turns away about 15 to 20 people per day. Osborne House in fact is a good example of how rooming houses can be saved. About six years ago a fire rating report meant that extensive works were required and the owner, St Vincent's Hospital, threatened to close down or demolish the building. Negotiations between Fitzroy City Council and the State Housing Ministry obtained a lease on the building for the City of Fitzroy and loan from the Ministry to do the essential renovations. The building is now managed by a local committee and the income from the rooms repays the loan and employs a manager. The State Ministry also maintains a limited buy-back program of rooming houses, but funds are limited. Inner urban purchase and renovation prices are so high that the program is but scratching the surface of a major social problem.

I raise these matters because of an urgent need for an injection of Federal funding to alleviate the problem. I am optimistic that the problem will be addressed in the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement currently being negotiated . There is an urgent need for funding to be earmarked so that a realistic buy- back program can be undertaken in the Melbourne electorate. Unless the matter is seen and treated as urgent, an integral part of our inner urban network and community will suffer increasing hardship and literally homelessness.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame on Cain.

—It is a shame on the capitalist system because it is under that system that this decline in the number of rooms has occurred. So the honourable member should not try to blame it on this Government. I am hopeful that the new Housing Agreement will bring about sufficient funds to allow the State Government to buy back these properties to enable needy people to be accommodated. I fail to understand why, when we talk about the needy in our society, honourable members opposite attack those honourable members who try to defend people in our communities. I acknowledge that the previous Liberal Government was involved in this. I acknowledge that the current Victorian Labor Government is involved. I am asking for more money to be made available. I do not see the necessity for those opposite to attack me when I bring an issue such as this before the House. Those opposite are not fair dinkum. They do not care about such people. That is why they interject with their smart, snivelling sidecracks whenever honourable members talk here about the oppressed people within our society. I am appalled that every time that occurs in this place those opposite try to score a cheap political point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) and the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch) for their comments on the second Sydney airport, though certain features of the comments of the honourable member for North Sydney disappointed me from several points of view. The first was that the honourable member for North Sydney is on record, as was my predecessor as Minister for Aviation, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Fife), as being in favour of the selection and acquisition of a second airport site for Sydney.
—In addition to.

—I agree they announced that in connection with their support for a close spaced parallel runway system which would have added very little to the capability of Sydney airport at very considerable expense.
—Nonsense.

—If the honourable gentleman has the opportunity to serve at some point in time as either a Minister for Aviation or an aviation shadow spokesman, which opportunity I doubt he will have, he will know that the principal purpose of establishing a parallel runway at an airport is effectively to create a second airport within the same airport. The objective of the parallel runway is effectively to get separate operations going. If that cannot actually be achieved, the sorts of benefits that would accrue from a parallel runway, effectively a second airport within the same airport, do not accrue and the sort of expense that we are looking at in constructing a parallel runway at Sydney would involve an inordinate amount of money for very little purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: For those sorts of reasons this Government has undertaken as effectively and as systematically as it can the oft-promised search for a second airport site in Sydney. The situation is complicated by the fact that we are under a variety of contradictory and odd pressures from people in areas that have been identified as potential areas by the Major Airport Needs of Sydney Committee. For example, one of the things I became determined about when I first started to examine this problem was that we were not going to go through a process whereby the MANS survey was accepted purely at face value and the two sites identified by the MANS study as suitable sites for an airport were accepted automatically by the Government.

There are many reasons why we did that. The first reason was that substantial development had taken place in both those areas since the report of the MANS Committee. I do not know about anybody else, but I felt myself under some sort of moral obligation to the people of those areas to take seriously the problems they raised with me. The second reason we have done that is that the type of airport we are looking for is in dimensions somewhat different from that implied in the MANS study where the search was for a total replacement of Kingsford- Smith. We have accepted the possibility that the airport may well operate not as a total replacement for Kingsford-Smith but in addition to Kingsford-Smith. If we are able to achieve that in the second site selection, the airport we select will be considerably different from that predicated in the MANS study and probably will require an area of about one-half to 60 per cent of that originally envisaged to be acquired. As honourable members would appreciate, that is a very substantially different problem for the Commonwealth Government than seeking a total replacement.

The third feature of that is that in attempting to identify a suitable site, given that we may well require a lesser area, the opportunity is there for an examination of sites to the south of Sydney. In going through an examination of sites to the south of Sydney, we shall have to do, on those sites, engineering studies of at least a reasonable amount of detail if we are to be able to make an appropriate judgment on them. The engineering studies that were done by the MANS Committee took a considerable period. The studies that we shall do will take considerably less time, but they will, nevertheless, be thorough.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired. If no other Minister rises to speak, the Minister for Aviation may continue until 11. 10 p.m.

—Our objective in achieving that is to give ourselves a reasonable choice when we finally come to determining what our position will be on the total aviation needs of Sydney. The propositions put forward by the honourable member for North Sydney, without actually moving to the acquisition and development of a second Sydney airport-and he undertook to do that when he was in government-would not have achieved a permanent solution to Sydney's problems. At best it would have achieved a very temporary solution. The honourable member for North Sydney implies that the Government has somehow reached a position where absolutely no development of any sort improving operations of Sydney will take place under this Government. If he really believes that, he has forgotten the detail of the last Budget. We included in the last Budget provision for the development of fast taxiways at Sydney, which will increase and improve the traffic flow there, and we shall also look at other technical developments. However, we shall not proceed, as was suggested, to the inordinate expense of going into the construction of a close-spaced parallel runway which alleviates not all-or it does marginally, but not permanently-the problems that are confronted at Sydney Airport.

SPEECH.PARA: To give honourable members some sort of comprehension of the dimensions of this matter, the lowest estimate of the cost of a close-space parallel runway at Sydney, which would require considerable fill in Botany Bay-and a very considerable argument would ensue over the environmental impacts of that-is an amount of $400m to $500m. It would probably be a great deal more than that. To build in my own electorate, for example, a runway that does precisely the same thing would cost about $20m to $30m. Extra runway development at Sydney must be considered very carefully from a cost point of view when one looks at an expense such as that. If we are able to select a site that does not, for example, require that degree of fill and that can effectively be operated on the plain that is there, the cost saving of that particular site simply over the development of a single runway, as opposed to what would be done in a close- spaced parellel non-permanent solution runway at Sydney, is an amount of, say, $ 30m stacked up against a minimum of $450m. So the process through which the Government is going, unlike the sorts of processes that honourable members opposite are obviously used to and therefore they automatically assume that what one has on one's hands is merely a political rather than an aviation problem, is very considerable.

If we are able to arrive at a satisfactory second site for a second Sydney airport-not a replacement Sydney airport-what we shall have achieved is an assurance of a permanent settlement of the aviation requirements of Sydney. In getting that extra site, we shall be looking at a capability for a 24-hour operation. No matter what one does at Sydney Airport, whether one goes for a close-spaced parallel runway system or a wide-spaced parallel runway system, what one will never get there politically is a 24-hour airport, and that is what is required at Sydney, as the major aviation centre of Australia. If Sydney cannot get a 24-hour airport, that will be the thing that is placed in jeopardy. One will not have just the honourable member for Barton up against one; one will never get a 24-hour airport on the current site of Sydney. So if Sydney is to maintain its reputation and its position, as I believe it should, as the principal aviation centre of Australia, it requires a second airport. It requires a second airport that is acceptable to the Sydney community. I shall not be pressed by honourable members opposite, including the honourable member from the area of Scheyville, into making a hasty decision, because I do not wish to do his electors or others the disservice of arriving at a conclusion that is not based on a full comprehension of the facts. A second airport site selection will receive the best shot and we shall be looking at the matter responsibly.
