ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Nuclear Research Facilities: Australian Capital Territory

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Territories and Local Government, upon notice , on 16 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What (a) nuclear research facilities and programs and (b) nuclear medicine programs, are being undertaken in the Australian Capital Territory.
(2) Is it a fact that these nuclear related activities are incompatible with the concept of a nuclear free zone.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) I am advised by officers of the Capital Territory Health Commission ( CTHC) which is the body responsible for monitoring such activities, that nuclear research programs are undertaken at three facilities in the ACT: two are associated with the nuclear medicine departments of the Royal Canberra and Woden Valley Hospitals; the other is at the Research School of Earth Sciences, where strategies to treat high-level wastes are being investigated by using simulated experiments-note that no radio-active materials are used for this purpose.
(b) Nuclear medicine programs undertaken by the Capital Territory Health Commission consist of radionuclide therapy, radionuclide diagnostic imaging and development programs using radionuclides.
(2) I believe there is no question of incompatability.

The Australian Nuclear Free Zones Secretariat which is responsible for fostering the declaration of nuclear free zones, has stated that its aim is not to seek to restrict the use of radio-active materials for medicinal purposes or basic research which is not aimed towards the development of nuclear weapons.

Many of the local government areas in Australia which have been declared as nuclear free zones contain medical and tertiary institutions which conduct similar nuclear programs. The existence of these activities in the Australian Capital Territory is therefore not inconsistent with the concept of a nuclear free zone.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 8 December 1983 :

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to question No. 606 (Hansard, 30 November 1983, page 3121) if rural automatic telephone exchanges will not be completely digital before the end of the century, does this mean that many of the newer information and communications technologies will not be available to many country people until that time and thus many years after city people receive it; if so, what can be done to accelerate the conversion of RAXs to digital rather than initially to newer analogue equipment.
(2) Is the replacement rate of RAXs adequate to maintain a first class service for country people as an accelerating percentage of these exchanges are no longer able to do so.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The program for installing digital switching equipment in the country will aim to provide a digital capability within economic reach of as many country customers as quickly as financial and manpower resources will allow.

Past experience has shown that the demand for improved facilities such as automatic service, STD, ISD, has been stronger in the higher population centres, where customers with active commercial interests predominate. In country areas, this means that the demand appears earlier in the larger towns than in the rural communities.
It is expected that, with future enhanced facilities, a similar pattern of demand will prevail, and this pattern will, to some extent, determine the program for installation of modern equipment.
That is, in general, the larger country centres will have new digital equipment installed at an early date, but this does not mean that the rural areas will be excluded from the program.

From the earliest date at which suitable digital equipment for the small rural exchanges can be made available (estimated to be 1987), there will be a very rapid phasing out of analogue equipment installations (as will also be the case in urban areas). Digital rural equipment will be installed: (a) to replace the remaining manual exchanges; (b) to replace the obsolete RAX step-by-step exchanges; (c) side by side with the more modern crossbar (ARK) exchanges to provide for customer growth requirements.

Because of the rapid spread of digital equipment, the new facilities will be available as an option to a high percentage of customers with a change in number . Customers requiring new facilities in areas where it has not yet been practicable to provide digital equipment will usually be able to be given the facilities by connecting them to the nearest centre where digital facilities exist.

The rural program will, therefore, be devised to provide the new facilities over as wide an area as possible, within the limits of available capital works funds, taking care not to jeopardise the program of converting the remaining manual exchanges to automatic working.

The actual level of demand for the new facilities is most difficult to predict at the present time. It is foreseen, however, that once the larger centres, and a selection of small exchanges, have received digital equipment, there will be an initial build up of the use of these facilities which will form a reliable base on which forecasts of on-going demand can be made.
(2) See answer to Question 1.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 28 February 1984:

ANSWER.PARA: Under the provisions of Division 3, Part XVI, of the Commonwealth Electoral Act , registered parties, candidates and groups of candidates will be eligible to apply for public funds in respect of expenses incurred for their election campaigns. Entitlements will be based on first preference votes received but the amount of a payment to the agent of a registered party, candidate or group will not exceed the electoral expenditure in relation to the election incurred by or with the authority of the party, candidate or group.

The Australian Electoral Commission has advised that a claim for payment must be supported by evidence relating to electoral expenditure incurred in relation to the election. For this purpose, 'electoral expenditure in relation to the election' includes all expenditure in connection with the election irrespective of when the expenditure was incurred. This means that the expenditure may have been incurred outside the election period so long as the Commission is satisfied that the expenditure was incurred in relation to the election. Electoral expenditure for this purpose is not limited to those items which must be disclosed in a party's or candidate's return of electoral expenditure under Division 5, Part XVI.
